Burger was spot on for flavor. I typically choose a burger with cheddar, bacon and bbq sauce. The Smokin BBoy delivered on it. However, the price at $18 is pretty outrageous. Especially because the burger is only 120g. Naughty fries are pretty delicious but are 10$. So a $30 burger and chips set. The rooftop garden is really nice for conversation and atmosphere. 3* for value. 4* for taste. 4* for ambiance.

One of the best burgers I have had in Singapore only because I haven't been able to find a half decent burger around. We had the Burning Man ($24) - the burger in itself had an overpowering taste of the Jalapeno relish. The bun was nothing special - it neither reduced or enhanced the taste. Left me needing a huge bottle of ice water to wash down the taste.Honkey Tonk ($18) - the chicken was done impeccably well. Was crisp, tender and moist. Again, the bun was just a filler. Personally, not a fan of chicken burgers but the execution of this was pretty good. Likely to go back for this one.Finished off with a Sticky Icky Wicky ($8) - was moist and was not too sweet. Coupled with the fresh cream topping, it was nice and balanced and easy on the palate. The ambience was great. The entire Duxton Hill area has a nice vibe to it and I loved the setting of the entire place. However, the service was really bad. From the girl at the counter who was in an extremely sour mood, to our server who cold shouldered us the whole night.

Ordered 2 Honky-Tonk, 2 drinks and a toffee pudding and we paid $62 in total. The price was exorbitant considering the burger tasted mediocre (nothing special). It had a lovely sauce on in, but just felt that for the price we were paying it should have been bigger or at least come with a side. NOTE: Honky-Tonk was the only chicken burger on the menu, can't speak for the other burgers.We were sitting on the 2nd floor and the place looked nice until the sun went down and it became dark. Would have been a better place to have lunch at instead of dinner in my opinion. We also had to wait 45 mins for our dessert. We were told that the kitchen was busy and that it took awhile to warm the pudding. This would have been okay if the pudding arrived steaming hot which was not the case. Plus, my friend's reservation to the 3rd floor lounge had to be released to someone else as we were still waiting for the dessert. Overall, in my opinion it is overrated and not worth the money. If you are coming for the ambience try coming at in the afternoon or for a early dinner and if you're lucky you would snag a seat at the rooftop bar too.
Was here with a friend and spent $70 for 2 drinks, 2 burgers and fries. The naughty fries are on the spicy side, get your ice water ready! Recommend to order Da Cheese Master burger!

*Great environment, but the food, while very tasty, is expensive for small portions*Invited a group of friends to join me for a casual dinner, and we all agreed that while the food here was really tasty, warm and full of flavor, the portions were far too small to justify the big price tag.  The cheapest burger, ~$15, was the kiddy burger, and the most expensive one was the $35 truffle burger.  Most of the other burgers ranged from $20-$25.It's strange because since the burger join is so close to a few different bus stops and MRT stops, it's easy to get to, and the atmosphere is great.  Chill music, nice wallpapering and overall a nice environment to go with friends or for a casual date.I'd love to give this place a 5-star review for their tasty burgers, but the food just isn't worth the prices they charge.

Food is just alright for all the hype that this place is getting. I would recommend the naughty fries but that's about it. Decent variety of burger. Tried baby Huey and honky tonk. Both are just alright. Service is not prompt and it's hard to get the waiters' attention. Maybe they are just busy. Roof top bar has a good vibe but considering the food/ price/ service I probably won't be back.

How about a very artsy joint for a burger place in Singapore in the middle of Chinatown.    I stayed across the way in a boutique hotel.   Potato head is deceiving as one will not perceive this to anything resembling a burger joint.   I only went there 3 times to have my American burger craving in the one week in Singapore.  It is a Bali based burger place.  The burgers are well made with a nice bread.  Not Cheap.  but in a pinch for a cold beer and a decent burger.   Hey.. they dont have In and Out in Singapore..  Yet..

5 for ambiance and 3 for food. So I gave it a 4. One of the more creative and interesting places to eat, drink and just hang out. I love the feel of the place.  I read and heard the service is bad and that they almost seemed bored.. but I have been there a few times and always had very good service and they were very attentive. I like that they take a different approach to food and drink menu and what they serve. Not typical Singapore where everything is essential the same..However, the execution of the food was just ok. I had the burning man burger which was spicy (which is great) but not alot of flavour and too much bun. Had the home made soda which was not all the good, but i like they don't go traditional. . But overall a great place to hang and I will go back.

LOVE the ambience and drinks at Potato Head. We went on a Saturday night for drinks on the rooftop (4th floor). There are all together four floors, each has different vibes and functions.  The rooftop felt like a tiki bar with cool décor - hanging lights, wired sculptures of animals, etc. They were playing reggae music which is great for the scene. It was pretty packed when we were there (11pm-1am) but you can definitely find standing room.The drinks are AMAZING but also pricy. Cocktails average about $25. They take their cocktail making super seriously! Our favs are Calypso, Zombie, and Age of Sage. Excellent rum selections too.We didn't get any food but will definitely be back for more.
Really like this place,  the vibe is cool a bit loud though so not a place for a quiet dinner.  Burgers are tasty, the buns are good as well. The crack a lacka corn wow this is good!!!

Delicious burgers and fries with a hip, urban vibe. We ordered the burning man burger, fries and 2 bottles of water.... Bill came out to $40 .... Little bit pricey but happy to pay that much if they maintain the quality. Looking forward to trying the upstairs outdoor bar/terrace once it opens as well as the indoor dining experience which is already open. We sat outside on a table and chairs and enjoyed the people watching while the fans kept us cool. The service was super friendly which was a nice bonus!

Love the ambiance and the quirky interior. My cocktail, truffle fries and chicken burger were on point, even if my tinder date wasn't. The darkness of the restaurant helped to mask the awkwardness. I'll be back with better company!

Something for everyone! Great venue with three themed floors that serve delicious burgers and drinks.  The rooftop is beautiful at night and the Studio Lounge is fun and unique. There is a wide selection of cocktails, many of which are included in happy hour specials, and although the wine selection is small, it offers great choices. We tried and loved tyhe Krabby Patty, James Brown and Rambo burgers.

Recommended.  And for once a great recommendation.  Not very hungry for lunch but I had the Baby Huey burger and couldn't stop eating until it was all gone, then I proceeded to eat all the fries.  And they aren't just ordinary fries - they have béarnaise sauce and beef chili on them.  The drinks i though were weak and not very interesting - more thought went into the description than the ingredients.  The ambience is a bit confusing, I think they were going for English fantasy garden but it just felt a little crowded and dusty.

Spent my new years eve here. Great ambience, great music, awesome artworks, fantastic burgers is all what makes this joint so special. Price is a little bit more than burgers out there but you pay that little extra for all that extra perks.Witty burger names, delicious burgers and fresh tasting salads makes me wanna come back.
It may sound bit harsh, but everything here is absolutely mediocre. The ambience was okay. There's no food item that stands out for me.

Went to Potato Head for cocktail week 2016 and once the staff finally pointed us to the proper bar where we could order the drinks, everything went smoothely.  The bartender made some solid cocktails and we feasted on fries in a relaxed 3rd floor atmosphere.  It is amazing how different the floor ambiances were.  I will go back for the rooftop bar scene and a tastey burger down on the bottom floor restaurant.

Alas, I had heard great things about the burgers and was sorely disappointed. Their sister restaurant in Bali is much better. I ordered the sliders and they just didn't deliver for me. I left hungry bc the server wanted me to take advantage of the happy hour deals, but that wasn't enough for me. And, they were very underwhelming sliders. I walked up all the levels, and the rooftop was entirely too hot. I ate on the third level and had people just eyeing me to leave my table, which I graciously chewed and drank slower just for them. There are so many more great places to go in the city.

I came here on a Thursday night with a group of friends looking for some good burgers and a chill place to hang out. Potato Head Folk was that and so much more. The decor is amazing and the vibe is 1930s casual.. add in some of the best burgers ever and you have one helluva place! I had the kids burger (dizzy rascal), a bit of the  burning man, some cracka lacka corn, and house fries. The dizzy rascal was just the perfect thing for me. Tasty and not too meaty. I had a bite of the burning man and it had a real spicy kick to it. The corn.... well, it was definitely "cracka lacka" flavorful. The fries were the only that were boring... but whatever. You can't win them all. I'll definitely be coming here again though!
Great atmosphere and staff, always a pleasure to come here. It's the place to have one more drink after a nice meal. Perfect location.

The best burger I have had thus far in Singapore!  Far better than a burger from Omakase in 3 major ways: 1). The bun is not soggy; 2). The beef was perfectly cooked - nice pink Medium; and 3). You could taste the bacon, as the slices were thick and smoky.  Naughty fries were also like a meal in itself.  The fries were interesting shaped - like long thin slices, and topped with chili beef and a spicy béarnaise sauce.  Awesome.   Now for what I didn't care for - the room, which looked like a tea room and not really my style.  And do not order their home made cola - it tastes nothing like cola.  But they have some beers and decent wines which go far better with the burgers so we shifted strategies.  Definitely go upstairs to the bar -1939.  Not sure if I should be breaking this into another review, but they definitely have a nice selection of booze and wines and their cocktails are solid.   The Brooklyn was spot on - not too sweet, and they did a perfectly solid version of an old fashioned with Rittenhouse 100 rye.  So far, in the uber competitive burger world in Singapore, Potato Head is my fave - far better than Omakase or db Bistro.

Really wish they would bring over the same menu as they have in Bali and not just burgers! Still though this place is a gorgeous venue with good vibes on weekends to entertain friends with decent variety (albeit super pricey) of drinks...just be sure to eat somewhere else first!

Finally! After so much talk about Potato Head, I've managed to pull a decent excuse off my exercise regimen to come savour the burgers here.... and fries *ahem*.My friend and I came on a Sunday evening, and the good thing is that the place was not crowded; it was easy enough to get a seat. The problem is that it is located in Keong Saik, which means parking is always a problem. Hence, you can get a seat, but most of the time you're not gonna find parking.Tried: Rambo and the Burning Man burgers. They are very delicious, although I wish they were bigger. The buns are baked from whole meal, making this a little more healthy compared to the sin I'll be ingesting.- The Rambo burger is mutton/lamb, which they managed to mask over the gamey taste with lots of spices and I believe... a blue-cheese kinda sauce? I might be wrong, but it sure tasted like it. The combination of the sauces and spices sure gave it a pretty unique taste.- The Burning Man, now we're talking. A nice slice of beef patty well grilled with mayo and ketchup, topped with Californian jalapenos to spice up the taste. It was good. However, the burning man's jalapenos has some serious zing into it, which was fine for me but not for my friend... you have been warned!- Also tried the Naughty Fries, which are basically fresh but soggy potato chips slathered with a generous dashing of cheese sauce and beef chili (the Mexican kind). It literally was one of the best cheese fries I had so far.Rants: Wish the burgers could be bigger. The sizes of these burgers remind me of what you can get from MacDonald's (no not the big mac). That's the reason why I had two burgers instead of just one. And the prices of each burger is kind of expensive ranging in the $20s, without any side dishes or fries or salads etc.. Burgers are tasty, but the pricing still leaves a bitter taste. You have been warned!Raves: The whimsical theme of the décor leaves a nice chill-out location if you're into these kind of things. Food is very tasty and makes u craving for more! Oh the top floor has a nice rooftop bar which oversees much of Keong Saik.

This place seems like it would be good from the outside appearance. Its super instagramable. I had pretty high expectations but after I saw the menu things changed. The food here is super expensive. Like 25 dollars for a burger the size of my fist. My sister ordered the burger and I was so shocked at how small it was.  It was literally a slider size.  I ordered the wings, which were meant to be appetizers but I got them as my meal. They weren't your average buffalo wings. The sauce on the outside was a spicy sweet chili sauce and there were spring onions and deep fried onions as garnishes. The outside was crispy and the flavor was unique.  They were probably the cheapest thing on the menu so I was actually pretty satisfied with my meal. The rest of the people that I went with got burgers and I felt so bad for them because of how much money they had spent on the smallest burger ever. Go here for average burgers if you don't mind over paying for them.

Anyone who rates these burgers less than 5 stars has their head firmly inserted in their ass. I've eaten burgers from Singapore to San Juan, from Stockholm to Santiago, and this is a delicious burger. I had the burning man. Extensive cocktail menu which was delicious. Only comment would be that the fries are pretty average and could certainly be improved. Other than that, shut up and eat your burger. It's 5 kinds of delicious.

Awesome space and decor, great small bites and service. We sat in the rooftop bar, and loved the space and vibe. Our waiter was very friendly. We had a couple of cocktails, all good, and tried several of the small bites. Tasty and easy snack and drink place for us!

on a cool night, this is a good place to have drinks on the rooftop.  my friend came during the weekend before and said it was packed, but on a tues, we were able to get a table.  we each got a calypso cocktail, which made us feel like we were on an island.  deliciously refreshing.

Excellent ambience and outstanding Lebanese / middle eastern food.  Great place for big groups and date nights.   We had the trolley dish, sides, mains and dessert - each of them is prepared with a lot of thought.  We started at 8 pm and it was rather quiet but the crowd built up by the time we left.  Will definitely go back.Caution: there are lots of nuts in each dish.  Not for those with nut allergy.

Great food, ambiance, and service. We tried five kinds of mezze (salmon tartare, red pepper and cheese paste, soup, mussels, and oysters) and loved them all. The fish main dish was also divine. Waiters were also very friendly and made us feel welcomed.

Beautiful food, friendly service, and great 2 for 1 lunch specials. This eatery does not disappoint. Tip: If you modify or try to substitute any of the dishes, it is no longer eligible for the 2 for 1 deal. We ordered a Caesar salad and asked for dressing on the side. The Romaine was crisp and fresh. The dressing was rich, full of flavor.We had the pizza with mushrooms and olives, the spaghetti al funghi, spaghetti bolognese, and the pasta carbonara. The pizza had a lovely crust, sauce and the ingredients were fresh. My niece slurped up every bit of spaghetti bolognese. The carbonara was good, but not the best I have had. My favorite entree was the lovely al funghi. I believe they had 3 different kinds of mushrooms and the sauce was so fragrant.Last but not least, the desserts were amazing. The gelato is freshly made with great flavors. The pistachio lava cake was rich and decadent and wonderfully balanced with the passionfruit sorbetto. The waffle with apple caramel was paired with chocolate gelato. Dessert was to die for. Thank you Chapter 55 for a fabulous meal.

My group of girlfriends, a total party size of 8 decided to check out Chapter 55 at hipster land. So I called in to make a reservation, but an automated voice answering machine told me I would receive a text message to complete the reservation, which I did. It was a short URL to make a reservation via Chope. However on Chope, I could only select a maximum party size of 6. So in the comments I asked for 2 more seats.A few hours later I got a call saying that their cafe's reservation policy requires each person to spend at least $25 and order a main course. Waffles which are priced $18.50+ with 2 scoops of ice cream are not considered a main course. Even the staff encouraged me to walk in. This is ridiculous. So we decided to walk in, and the food better be worth the effort!Despite the phone call, I was delighted to be greeted by the beautiful ice cream display!And I pinched myself to be sure I wasn't dreaming when I saw the $23 per pint price tag. Okay, let's see if their ice cream is really twice as good as other competitors, to be priced this high.The interior has a very homely, retro feel to it, the lighting isn't instagram's best friend. You will have to improvise or try and get a table by the windows.1. Beef Bolognese Cheese Fries $15+With truffle tries price at $14, we decided to try something else. Sadly, this dish wasn't what we expected, even though there is supposedly cheese in the sauce. We couldn't taste any. It was a plate of very soggy fries, with a very under seasoned beef bolognese sauce.2. Squid Ink Risotto $25+Tasted cheesy and I felt gerlat very quickly. This is the first plate of Risotto that I didn't like, I am normally a huge fan of Risotto.It's waffle time! Despite the unsatisfying experience with the main courses, I was so certain the highly instagrammable waffles with ice cream would be the highlight of my night!3. Waffles with Mao shan wang durian and belgian chocolate $18.50+I liked that the durian ice cream colour wasn't overly yellow, which a lot of ice cream parlours, normally add yellow colouring to, it didn't smell very fragrant but it tasted good. I liked the durian ice cream. The Belgian chocolate tasted okay, it didn't leave an impression for me. The waffles, which I was looking forward to, tasted ok, I've definitely had better waffles in the surrounding area.4. Waffles with Pulut Hitam and Pistacchio $18.50+The only redeeming factor that Chatper 55 had for me tonight, was the Pulut Hitam ice cream, which I truly enjoyed. However not all the girls at my table liked it. It wasn't displayed, but they had it in the freezer. You could bite into the black rice bits in the ice cream. It a legit, pulut hitam ice cream! The Pistacchio was also a memorable ice cream flavour. You can distinctively taste the pistacchio.The bill for 6 girls and we weren't very big eaters, so asking all 6 of us to order a main course each isn't the wisest cafe policy, even from a business stand point.The staff weren't well organized and took a long while to clear our table. The first staff cleared one plate, and a male staff cleard 2 more plates. We were done with all our plates and when the waffles came, we still had half a table worth of dirty plates. Only after the second waffle came to our table, did another male staff who served us the waffles, clear the rest of the dirty dishes.The chinese local lady at the cashier who spoke mandarin was very friendly and polite. I had higher hopes for their ice cream and waffles with such a high price tag on each plate. On the bright side, they have BOGO weekday lunch offers.wifi password : chapter55

Great place for their 1-for-1 weekday lunch promotion and it accommodated our group of about 12. No problems getting a seat at 11.30am on a Friday.Vongole spaghetti ($18) - 3.75 starsHearty, more clam shells than meat, but at half the price I'm not complaining.Strawberry gelato ($4.80) - 3 starsToo sweet after the first few spoons.

My colleague who had accidentally ran into this bistro a week ago bugged us to accompany her soon to sample the food. So today, despite the heavy afternoon rain, we walked from our office to sought out the place. Walking along Eng Hoon Street, the restaurant was easily noticeable by the corner of Tiong Poh Road. It's pretty big. One thing that I found very attractive on their signboard was how they highlighted their "1 for 1 on weekdays" offer.We went as a group of 5. Seeing that the restaurant is not Halal-certified, I couldn't try out their main courses, hence I went with the desserts. Like one of the popular quotes that I snapped stated, "Life is short. Eat dessert first!"The appetizers came as bowls of mushroom soup. The mushrooms weren't in chunky forms but they were grounded in, which was nice!Two of my colleagues ordered one plate of white wine pasta (Vongole?) and the other, some sort of seafood pasta. Can't recall the names of the dishes, but both of them commented that the spices in both of their pastas were too overpowering; one even masked the white wine sauce. They also ordered buffalo wings (5 pieces). Personally, from what I see, those wings were overpriced. Such small pieces for $16?!Came my Salted Caramel Waffle and a glass of Black Cow. Funny names to give the floats: "Black Cow" for Coke Float and "Snow White" for Sprite Float. Well, as you can see from my waffle photo, I just loved the presentation. What a plating! Loved how they stenciled in cocoa powder of their logo at the corner of the plate. The waffle itself cost me $17 due to the fact that I opted for 2 scoops of ice-cream. Otherwise it would have been $15 for one. I opted for a scoop of Salted Caramel and Hazelnut gelato on my waffle, while I got another scoop of Hersheys gelato for my coke float. Loved the waffle!We even sampled a teaspoon of some of the gelatos on display. I had the Salted Egg flavoured, Cotton Candy flavoured and Strawberry Cheesecake flavoured... Nice. But definitely, I have tasted better and creamier gelatos elsewhere.

This place opened late last year in December right before Christmas and occupied a spacious corner on Tiong Bahru Road.  It is on way home and I noticed that it was always packed at night so I wanted to give it a try.  We went for Sunday brunch and I have to say I was skeptical at first because their menu was so extensive.  Usually when a restaurant is trying to offer everything it is a bad sign - on top of their brunch menu, they have a long list ranging from pasta to pizzas to risottos to appetizers and desserts (waffles, pancakes, gelatos). We ordered buffalo wings to share, I remember it being decent but not particularly authentic but on the spicy side.  The dish that blew me away was one of their fresh pasta dishes. The sauce was AMAZING, it is very flavorful and seems to be saffron based.  The seafood was very fresh, which is quite a rarity when eating out and reflects their attentiveness in sourcing ingredients.  It is also very reasonably priced.  To be honest, it was really out of my expectations.  I later read from other reviews that the chef is from Pasta Brava - that explains it.  Also read that its owner is the same as Ice Edge Cafe, a popular cafe in Kovan (ok too far for me so good they open one in TB). I tried a piece of the pizza that my friend was having, the crust was pretty good too.  The pasta was really filling as the sauce was so rich, so I didn't have any room for desserts.   That is a pity though as they appears to serve a great selection of gelatos.   I read that they have a 1-for-1 pasta deal during weekday lunch time and that's a pretty good deal, I would totally take advantage of this if I work around Tiong Bahru.  This is a pretty big space and can accommodate any group dining comfortably.

i like the one for one lunch deal even though there are limited choices for it.and you got to go there early to get a table if not you'll have to wait in line or sit outside in the heat of the day. my friend and I both had pizza; she ordered the bonito and i ordered the good old funghi pizza. it didn't leave me swooning but i'd say it's definitely one of the better pizzas i had in Singapore. the bonito was interesting to try but i am not sure if i want to order it again. pizzas are still better eaten the Italian way than fusion is my take on this. give me sausages, funghi and olives on a pizza anytime!!it was actually nice to have a gelato counter in store; the server was friendly and willing to give in to our undying want of trying almost all the flavors and then still smile at us as we try to make up our flippant minds. some were misses like the yuzu lacked the tangy taste i desire and the passion fruit mango was more like just mango. eventually i went for the belgium dark chocolate which i think is one flavor that could never go wrong and i was right. oh to note, they do have pretty powerful tasting mao shan wang gelato.in all I paid $20 for a pizza, a drink (nothing worth mentioning even though it was lemon grass) and a scoop of gelato.

I'm surprised this place rates so low. It's a popular lunch spot among my colleagues because of the buy one get one free lunch deal, and the fact that the food is pretty goodThey don't take reservations for lunch on weekdays, but it wasn't a problem for our party of 17. We made sure we arrived by 12pm to get a table. The menu that qualifies BOGO isn't large, but it's still decently diverse. You don't have to get the same item, just anything on the BOGO menu. A lot of people got the salmon with balsamic vinegar, and the Dory main dish was pretty popular too. I had the beef lasagna, which I thought was excellent. At half the price, it was a steal. The service was not outstandingly bad or good.Definitely a good place for a fancier lunch.

3 stars! 1 star each for FOOD, AMBIENCE and "WILL I COME BACK?". No stars for service and price.Also, I apologise in advance for the epic length review.The word 'hipster' is overused, really. This is a typical brunch restaurant. I don't see where it's 'hip' or 'ster'.Food is average. Mushroom soup is not Campbell's. Or at least to my un-hipster taste buds. Buffalo wings were like sweet and sour chicken wings, not spicy. Pasta was meh. The only thing I would come back for are the pizzas, Super thin crust and light. Nice.Ambience is homely. Lots of wood benches and tin pails for decoration. Seats are tightly packed and walk space is narrow. I might have seen a mason jar or two. /shudder"Will I come back?" Yes, for the pizza and for the "buy 1 get one free" lunch special. Now the mechanics of this BOGO is dreadfully complicated and very sneaky if the customer is not careful. I will explain this in the next section. This would have been so easy to fix when asked, and would have won a life-long customer. But. hey, which restaurant manager would want to do that?Service is non-existent. Poor guys are overworked and do not have time for pleasantries. Price. Ahhh, the only thing this place has going for it is the 1 for 1 lunch special. When you get seated, you will see from the menu that not all items qualify for this. Items that do, have a little label next to it.So! Imagine the following scenario:Ah Beng and Ah Lian decide to try this new 'simi-lai eh hipster' cafe near Ah Mah's flat in Tiong Bahru.They order two muchroom soups ($11 for 2) This items is automatically 1 for 1. Don't know why they have to make life so confusing.Then Ah Beng orders a Vogole pasta MAIN for $18. Ah Lian orders a Funghi Pizza for $18.For appetisers, Ah Beng orders Buffalo Wings ($16) and Ah Lian orders Calamari Rings ($16).So, quick recap: 2 soups, 2 mains, 2 appetisers.QUESTION: How much was Ah Beng and Ah Lian charged for their lunch? (Assume no service charge.)ANSWER: You would think, this is easy! 1 for 1 mushroom soup + 1 for 1 MAIN + 1 for 1 appetiser = $11 + $18 + $16 = $45Wrong. Because Chapter 55 is so scared that customers will 'take advantage' of the 1 for 1 deal, this is how they calculated the bill:Mushroom soup is $11 for 2. (Written in the menu, don't argue.)Higher cost items are charged, lower cost items are free. (Written in the fine print, don't argue.)Actual bill is: $11 + $18 + $18 = $47Ah Beng and Ah Lian pays up and leaves, vowing to never come back and also something about mothers and fathers.Ok, ok, the story is a little dramatic for a difference of $2. But it is the principle of the whole thing. Even if it is not for principle, then it is about making a quick decision to make Ah Lian and Ah Beng happy customers. Long story short: After the trauma of mathematics and Chapter 55. Ah Beng and Ah Lian grew closer and lived happily ever after,

Had dinner here last night with family and friends. Our group of 6 had buffalo wings, pesto salad, truffle fries. Squid ink risotto, osso buco, mushroom pasta and anchovy pizza with Bonito flakes. We also had a few scoops of gelato for dessert. I got salted caramel, which was good but not the best I've ever had.All the dishes were good. The wings were juicy and spicy and the risotto was creamy, although a bit stingy with the shrimp and scallop (there was only 1 piece of each in the dish). Service was pretty fast and friendly.The place was almost full, which showed the terrible acoustics. There was a group of 8 seated about 3 meters away from our table and their loud chatter and laughter echoed. The table size is odd too--- definitely squeezy for 6, too roomy for 4. Overall it is a nice casual Italian place, and I would consider going back.
Great food and chill atomosphere. Waffles and gelato were soooo good.  Had chicken salad and risotto and both tasted great. Other food items look good as well.

Came here on a Saturday afternoon and it was very quiet and relaxing atmosphere. The lemon grass tea is fantastic and the beef risotto taste amazing. This is the first time I have good Italian in Asia!!

Chapter 55 is right in the heart of Tiong Bahru and, literally, just a short walk away from where I work. I ended up coming here with my husband for lunch and we were super stoked to utilize the 1-for-1 deal. It's unfortunate though, the pizza and the pasta we ordered were pretty bland... But the gelato was super rich and creamy and did make up for the mediocre lunch.

Tiong Shian Eating House is conveniently located right inside Chinatown on New Bridge Road. The place is just 5 minutes walking from Clarke Quay. Food here is tasty, authentic and reasonably cheap. Frog porridge has an undoubtable sweet taste. The frog is chewy, moist and juicy. We really love to drizzle extra sesame oil on top, which obviously gives an interesting twist to the taste. Century eggs porridge, in addition, blows us away with its creaminess and fragrance. Apart from being a perfect treat to have on a rainy day, a bowl of century egg porridge is also great for people who are sick, as it's wholesome and hearty.Recommendation: Frog porridge and century eggs porridgeRead our Singapore Food Guide: thecoupleeats.com/singap…

Awesome Porridge! Even better "sides". I was in Singapore for business and was taken here by my coworker. She ordered everything. It's not fancy at all, just tables on the sidewalk. As always with night market vendors, find a table, then go get food. Food was so flavorful. I wish I could go back!!

The flurry of 4 star ratings for this place really puzzles me. Came here with a friend on a Monday night at 10pm (they apparently close on alternate Mondays so we got lucky).We got a bowl of century egg porridge with an added raw egg, a pot of gongbao frog, plain porridge, and some raw fish. I really wasn't impressed with the century egg porridge, because I only tasted the soy sauce they liberally put, and it was watery and insipid. The raw fish was reasonably fresh, with chilli, lime, ginger; nothing spectacular, and the frog was just... meh. I don't know how much this place costs... but any price is too much for this (lack of) standard(s).

Location is at Chinatown, just beside CK department store opposite People's park complex. There are many choices of porridge to choose from and it was tasty - one of the better ones over here. Besides that, there are selection of side dishes to choose from and the ones my friend ordered were pretty tasty. This eating place opens until late at night and is popular among the locals and after trying it for the first time, I certainly recommend it.

No frills coffee shop near chinatown, supposedly porridge is awesome so dragged my parents here on Sunday after church to check it out!Pick your dishes and order/pay at the little counter.We paid:1. $4.20 for yusheng - not bad, but there were bones! are there supposed to be bones?? I was somewhat confused. I guess they are edible, but somewhat disconcerting to feel the texture on one's tongue, nonetheless2. $8.80 for claypot gong bao fish slices - pretty gd sauce, wasn't very thick sauce, but went well with the plain porridge3. $5 for you choy (sauteed veg) - shanghai greens, apparently. Mom buys these veges from NTUC regularly, very easy to steam. Anyway, came with nice sauce! Garlic soy mixture of some sort.4. $0.60 per bowl of plain porridgeI wasn't super-wowed, but it's a fairly good meal for the price. It's kind of hot there though!

Since CNY is round the corner, why not head down to Chinatown for a little squeeze with the crowd at the street market and have a sumptuous frog-leg porridge to round up the experience! The portion is pretty generous and the gravy is not too spicy. For a tender tongue like mine that cant tolerate too much spiciness, this is great. If you want a kick for your tastebuds, just ask them to up the intensity of the spiciness! Add a plate of raw fish to increase your appetite as the freshness of the fish doused with the acidity of the lemons livens up your tummy.Fresh, flavourful and warm. One word - YUMS.

There is only one place to go for supper in Chinatown and that is Tiong Shian. It is so popular that there are always cars and people clustered around the corner coffeeshop even at 11pm. Having had work in the area before, its one of the few decent food options available by that hour. Word of advice though for those who drive, good luck finding parking. And when business is brisk, good luck finding a table too. As the name states, they are famous for their porridge. Every possible kind with every possible ingredients / toppings is available here. Called me a traditionalist, but I often go with the staple Pork porridge with century egg. I like the portion sizes especially after a long day at work or play for you clubbers out there. As with most supper porridge stalls, they also serve frog legs porridge. And for those of you who irk at the thought of eating kermit, I will tell you the same thing my parents told me when I was a kid squirming at the very same idea, "It tastes the same as chicken, only much nicer!". Its really true as frog meat is lighter and sweeter in texture, and the flavours goes into making the porridge sweet and light too.And for more variety sake, they also serve a very good standard bbq chicken wings and also raw fish (chinese style not japanese sashimi) to go with plain porridge if thats your cup of tea.

To call Tiong Shian an institution in Chinatown is hardly an overstatement. Their porridge is among the best, if not the best in Singapore (and that's not an exaggeration either). Alas, it's so popular (and parking in the vicinity so scared) that sometimes, there's a long queue for the tables. Fortunately, they have recently expanded their premises into the shop at the back (in addition to the unit above) which helps with crowd (but not the car parking). Their porridge comes in many different variety - pork, fish, chicken, cuttlefish, etc. The porridge is in fairly large portion too. In addition, Tiong Shian offers a large assortment of side dishes that you can order to go along with your porridge. You can be spoilt for choices (the regulars, however, will always pick the same stuff that they like).

Most people will know of this place for supper but standard has since dropped so much that I feel it is not worth visiting anymore. The porridge is blend and doesn't live up to its name.There is also a second floor above the coffee shop to choose to have your porridge.What most people order is the frog leg with porridge but I usually get the century egg with lean pork meat porridge.Although there are many who agree with me that standard has dropped but it really is a good place for supper and there are still long queues throughout the nights/

Tong Shian is most famous for its porridge and frog legs, but those are not the dishes that bring me here on a regular basis. Yes, the porridge is good, but the side dishes are the ones that really stand out and make the trip to Chinatown worth my while. I always order a plate of their bean curd, vegetables and raw fish. The bean curd is generously sized and nestled in a delicious sauce, whilst the raw fish is simply prepared with lime, chilli and ginger. I don't think I could ever get tired of either of these dishes. It can get pretty crowded, and you may have to wait a while for tables on a busy night. They have more tables at another outlet besides the small provision shop, so take a walk down that way if the main area on New Bridge road is full. To order, you will need to make your way to the cashier, so don't expect to have anyone come by and ask what you'd like to have.

The porridge here is good and the side dishes you can order makes dining here worth the trouble of searching for parking .There's a large selection of choices for porridge (usually pork for me), and they come in fairly large sizes. Throw in an egg, add a couple of side dishes and you'll have a sumptous spread for supper that anyone would be pleased to have!

The store is inside a normal hawker center, opposite CK shopping mall. Tiong Shian sell porridge and claypot frog with different variety and reasonable price. The store is open air and without air conditioner. Tiong Shian operates from 8 am - 4 am. It will be a good place for dinner and supper. The atmosphere here is great at night with hot porridge. You have to make your order and payment at counter and inform them your table number. They will serve your foods within 20 min. Out of so many varieties, a must have item are dried chili claypot frog with plain porridge. The plain porridge with the sauce is yummy, but the porridge too diluted. You can order other side dishes like vegetables, tofu etc with the porridge.

address: 48 Bukit Pasoh Rd Level 2 Singapore 089859 Singapore
comment: This place is beautifully decorated, has an amazing wine selection, and most importantly has outstanding service and food. Highly recommend for special occasions like an anniversary, a birthday, etc. The staff will make you feel very special and well taken care of. The Chef personally went around to explain some dishes. The night I went, there was a special dish on the menu and the scallop was out of this world, super juicy and well seasoned after been baked in its own shell. You really can't go wrong with any of the dishes but I'd recommend - tete au veau, super tender and melt in your mouth- trippes et caviar: quite rich and super crispy and delicious - champignions au vin jaune: super umami - lobster bisque: interesting twist, almost curry like - Mille feuille: IMO best dessert on the menu, so refreshing and good, has a good amount of citrus. if you're a chocolate lover then definitely do the mousse

I've been to this place twice this year and I have to commend their staff. They were very busy tonight but everyone was still nice and friendly. I love the happy hour deals and I enjoyed the food on both visits. Ladies night is on Wednesdays, you get a bottle of cava on top of their 1 for 1 drinks! :)

Nice little spot with some nice tapas and inexpensive cava. Very nice atmosphere in the area as well as the restaurant itself. The food and cava are good, not necessarily incredible but very affordable and good quality for the price.  Would definitely go again if I'm ever back in Singapore.

After dining on Asian cuisine our entire trip to Singapore, this burst of French flavor was more than welcome. Everything was simply superb. When I go home, I'm not going to remember the Asian dishes I sampled as much as I'll remember this meal and our great service.We had a beetroot hummus, fried gnocchi, and ravioli to split between us. The ravioli featured the best use of artichoke I've ever had, and the cream sauce left a feeling of decadence. My husband got the pork as an entree which was cooked very well with caramelized onions, and if anything they could have gone for a stronger ginger flavor.Our waiter, Kid, was a delight. He helped us order and was so personable and attentive. This was by far the best service we've had in Singapore.
Nice French cafe serving classic French fare and great brunch food. We got the Tarte flambé and eggs Benedict. Both were good, nothing spectacular but solid dishes both.

Absolutely love this place! Forgot the name of the waiter, but he was very passionate in his job and took his time to specifically present us all the available cheeses for that day. I highly recommend the tarte flambee, and one cream dumpling pasta dish (forgot the name). Recommend pairing with a bottle of rose from their wine selection!

Found my favorite croissant in Singapore! Light and flaky on the outside, soft and warm on the inside. Also had the eggs benny. It was just okay. The hollaindaise was abit too thick. The french toast was not bad. I would probably just go here again for the croissant, a coffee, and the beautiful ambiance. Small place, service could be much better, but people don't seem to mind since it's always busy! Even during weekdays it is busy so it's best to go early, make reso, or prepare to wait.

Lovely place to eat. Nice atmosphere. Too little portion of yoghurt with the delicious homemade granola, however the french acting show Bonjour! And Au revoir! Is also little annoying after 5 minutes. Great staff!
Absolutely phenomenal place for brunch! Eggs Benedict was cooked perfectly. Waited about 15 mins for a table for 3, and service is exceptional!!

address: Chinatown Complex Food Centre, 335 Smith Street Stall No. 3, Chinatown Complex Singapore 050335 Singapore
comment: Love, love, love, love the Satay here!!!! I've not had it in a while - but had some 2 weeks ago and I LOVED it. It's really hard to get Pork Satay and I remember lovin' it in Bali - when I had Pork Satay almost every other day - so it was a pleasant surprise to mix and match, Chicken, Pork and Lamb Satay - and the marinade is really yummy. The Satay turned out great and the peanut sauce was excellent too.What I Love: Service was great - the guy who took my order was a young chap, and was eloquent, and did the satay pretty quickly. Ketupat is free, when you order 10 pieces. You will get Ketupat, since minimum order is 10 pieces anyway. The meat was tender, tasted great, and flavors were just yummalicious! It's great to have satay, drink Coconut Juice, and sit out, looking at all the colorful lanterns. Great ambiance. What I Don't Love: Absolutely nothing!

address: Chinatown Complex Food Centre, 335 Smith Street Stall No. 3, Chinatown Complex Singapore 050335 Singapore
comment: Really good Satay!!! Try them all - pork, beef, chicken, shrimp, lamb

Had a Shack Stack. Very nice. Tasty & juicy.Fries with cheese also nice. Only problem is that I couldn't seem to cut through the mushroom. Better than the one I had in New York City because they brought out 15 in one go and mine was no longer hot.Good service but the lady who asked for feedback came a little too close for comfort in these Covid-19 days.

Much, much, much better than the Jewel branch. We were nearby during its official launch last Friday, so of course, we have to drop by and see (out of curiosity). I was expecting a long queue but to my surprise, there wasn't! We were there around 9-ish. There were over-enthusiastic staff cheering and screaming and giving high fives as we were walking in, I thought I was there to buy an iPhone for a split second. LOL. Queueing up to order was a breeze as there were 4 counters and at least 30 staff in the kitchen churning out burgers, fries, "concretes" and milkshakes so efficiently. Very impressive. The wait was manageable, around 20 mins for our order. There was also staff on the dining floor assisting customers with any queries, passing them cutleries, interacting with kids and basically being a great ambassador to the brand. The dining area is big and spacious enough with lots of seating booths, tall tables, and plants. Now onto the burgers - I tried various burgers from Shake Shack before, so I decided to try Chick'nShack. Delicious chicken breast slow-cooked in buttermilk marinate and then fried to perfection served with lettuce, pickles, and buttermilk mayo. Good stuff. We also tried the "concretes" - a term used for frozen custard blended with mix-ins. The Shack Attack is the regular cant-go-wrong chocolate mix, but my new found favorite will have to be Eye of the Tiger which is vanilla custard blend with lychee and top with lime zest. Refreshing and not too heavy on the palate. Overall, a pleasant visit and first-time experience at the new Shake Shack branch in the city. I can't wait to be back soon!

I was really looking forward to trying this spot as I have heard a tremendous amount of good reviews about this spot, since they do not have any halal food me and my family went for the vegetarian "shroom burger" it was really good, you get something good for what you pay basically. The staff was really friendly and had a good attitude, however at the end of our dinner when we were throwing away the trash they had not placed a bin and the sauce fell on my family members pants. Overall a very successful choice to go here, highly recommended.

I had a regular hamburger in New York and wasn't impressed. In and out seemed better (although I haven't had that in a loong time) and the frozen custard was way too sweet I threw away most of it. I was later told it's the portobello mushroom that's popular so I tried that.Shrooms burger - 3.5 starsThe deep fried portobello mushroom stuffed with cheese was interesting - it was juicy and filling, but the cheese tasted like your regular hamburger processed cheese. For me, the bread is usually a dealbreaker. Their buns were par for the course.Cheese fries - 3.5 starsFor starters, I wouldn't have gotten cheese fries if I'd known the portobello was stuffed with cheese. The fries were hearty and fried well. Not too bad.
A little disappointed with the burger as there was so much hype about it. It was a decent burger but not amazing like everyone else described :( staff were very friendly tho!!

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Was there during Restaurant Week so the value was really really good : $35++ for the whole meal, with a very good seared tuna first, then an okay salmon and a great apple crumble for dessert.Would definitely recommend it for a proper french bistrot dinner experience at a reasonable price (compared to fine dining), about S$150 for a dinner for two with some wine I would say.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: I've been wanting to try Taratata for awhile, as the menu looked promising.  It's classic French, and the restaurant enjoys a prime location on Keong Saik Road.  And inside, it looks like a classic bistro.  Stopped by for lunch earlier, and while the menu looked good, the execution was not as good.  I started off with French Onion soup which was ok, but the portion was quite small.  The main was a pork chop, but it was underseasoned, and the presentation was very underwhelming (see my photo).  And while they had a decent wine list, charging $30 for the cheapest red wine by the glass seems a bit too much, even in Singapore.  So overall, while the ambiance and menu hits the mark, the execution does not.  And with wine prices among the highest that I have encountered in Singapore, the price-value ratio isn't there either.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Dining out is an experience that involves many senses. You want to TASTE and SMELL the good food. The service matters too- is the waitress being attentive or is the waitress ignoring you? The atmosphere matters a lot too. Is the restaurant dirty, are there flies trying to attack your food? Is the music too loud so you have to scream?Well, Taratata Bistrot is a cute French restaurant that serves excellent French food. Unfortunately, the staff was incapable of controlling their overly loud and possibly drunk customers. The 4 course set meal was $70++ per person, on top of that, we ordered wine which was over $100. We came here to enjoy a nice delicious meal but the large table behind was a nightmare. A few women in particular kept cackling at the top of their voice like witches. This is a nice restaurant, this is not a circus. If you want to be loud and obnoxious, go to the hawker center. We complained to one of the waitresses but she seemed too afraid to tell the next table to tone it down. We then told another waitress and she just smiled, as if she didn't understand us. Finally, we got so annoyed that we left. We told them we were leaving because of the noise and they still did nothing. I am going to talk about the food briefly, it is pity that the food was delicious yet we were not able to enjoy it. The cod was good. The cheese platter for desert was excellent- you get to choose your cheese from a cheese cart, which they do in France. The problem is that it was hard to hear the explanations about the different cheeses because of the obnoxious table next door. Bottom line: the waiters and waitresses should not be afraid to tell customers to be more considerate. If these customers are really drunk, do not be afraid to refuse to serve alcohol to them. (I am not sure if our table was drunk or not, but it is a possibility. Either way they were extremely loud.) It is a small restaurant, one loud table is enough to ruin the experience for everyone else. Either way I am not coming back. Just only because I don't spend over $130 per person on a meal but feel like I am in a hawker center.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Classic bistrot décor (with French music in the background) and classic bistrot food - nothing particularly innovative (so, for instance, no sweetbread or rabbit), just well-executed traditional brasserie dishes. We had the escargots, foie gras poêlé, entrecôte grillée, confit de canard, and tarte fine aux poires, and they're all yummy. Reasonable pricing; the set lunch represents great value. Decent wine list. Add to this friendly service. Fir sure, we will go back.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: I've been on the lookout for good french food in Singapore and this place turns out to be that little gem where you can make a reservation relatively last-minute (about an hour before) and still get a seat for Friday evening dinner. And the food and wine are both good and at a "reasonable" price point (well, relative to the likes of famous French fine dining establishments like Les Amis and Gunther's).As a starting point, we took their wine recommendation, a Fort Duroc 2007 Medoc Vieilles Vigne (thanks Vivino!). Most of their wines are in the low 90s to $200++ range and their special was going at $108 a bottle. The "house wine" turned out to be quite complex and delicious, and given that this was at the lower end of their prices for wine, not what I'd expected them to push. A good start already!We had escargot for starters - suffice to say, the other reviews on this page have it spot on. Excellent, excellent dish.The highlight of the night had to be my main - duck confit French style ($33). Duck confit is not an easy dish to do well, based on restaurant experiences in Singapore. Typically the duck meat gets too dry or the skin is too soggy. I'm happy to share that they did this dish perfectly - the meat was moist, succulent and tender but the skin perfectly crispy and hot. Easily the best duck confit I've had in Singapore!Despite a slight hiccup in food service (our other order for main came 20 minutes late), the servers were at their best attending to us to make sure that we could share the duck confit (while we waited), and also gave us complimentary sorbet at the end of the night to make up for their mistakes. Like most good French places in Singapore, this place is not cheap (but not quite out of the stratosphere expensive). That said, good food, good wine and good service - I'm definitely coming back!

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Taratata Bistrot is a charming little French restaurant along Keong Saik Road which I've been meaning to try for sometime. I finally made time for it when i saw that it was on the Restaurant Week listing (yes i'm slow in updating) and it was only $25 for a 3 course meal. The prices are very reasonable even if you didn't make the RW bookings though. We were served starters from their regular menu, which is a good thing i feel. I hate it when restaurants serve a completely different (usually substandard) menu for RW. That kinda deters repeat visits especially if the food sucks.The Half Dozen of Snails Baked in Herbed Garlic Butter ($25). I found the escargots to be succulent and well flavored with garlic herbs. The Baked Eggs Casserole with Duck Gizzard Confit and Mushrooms ($24) had nice runny eggs that are best soaked up with the delicious baguette Taratata serves. Generous pieces of foie gras were swimming in the eggs but i thought they would be better seared first before thrown into the ramekin.Even though the mains were not from the regular menu, we were very happy with our dishes. The Salmon Coulibiac with Watercress Butter Sauce was lovely! The puff pastry was buttery and flaky and the salmon was cooked to a nice pink. The Pan Roasted Kurobuta Pork Tenderloin with Mustard sauce was done simply to allow diners a taste of the tender and non fatty meat. It's the first time i thought that pork could taste so clean and healthy. K thought it was a little too bland though.Dessert was the highlight of the meal! The Baked Chocolate Tart with Crisp, Caramel sauce and Ginger bread ice cream was out of this world. The crunchy tart held the intense chocolate lava and the pastry skin twirl made us twirly whirly in our seats as we devoured the dish without speaking (but we did make a lot of oooohs and aaaahhhhs. God they need to put this on their menu.Service was attentive and quick, maybe because they wanted us out fast for their second lunch service. If you're up for some quick lunch, Taratata Bistrot does a 40 minutes Lunch Express at $25 which includes a soup and a main course. For a more leisurely lunch, there's the $30 2-course set lunch and they also serve a 3 course set meal for $38. I'd recommend Taratata Bistrot for a charming and affordable French meal.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Perfect French bistrot, 2 French chefs, Bertrand and Philippe gave us a memorable classic and authentic French dinner.The lamb cutlets were so tasty, i found them better than some i had in a 3 stars michelin in France. A very nice cheese selection, reasonable and excellent wine list.Friendly and professional service.We will come back, we were back to France for few hours!!! Thank you.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: It was a great experience even though we skipped the mains and had 3 appetisers plus four desserts. French Onion SoupThis was done exactly the way I wanted it to be. Cheesy toast which was soaked in the savoury goodness. There was also some cheese crust that stuck stubbornly to the edges around the exterior pot that you should not waste. just use your hands to pluck them into your mouth. Once you dig in, there seemed to be endless amount of soft onions Escargots in herbed garlic and butterEscargots lovers must not miss this dish and it's recommended that you go for the dozen on the ala carte menu if you find that the 6 little ones on the sunday set menu insufficient to satisfy your craving. Crab and Pomelo SaladThis might not be commonly seen on French menu but it's certainly a refreshing starter to have. The crab meat hidden by the greens were fresh, sweet and creamy. Reminds me of a dense coleslaw without the vegetables. The pomelo was bitter but matched well with the crab. These 3 dishes were followed shortly by 4 desserts, which were mostly accompanied with a pot of creme anglaise. Prune Clafoutis with Rum and Raisin Ice creamThis was unexpectedly good as this French dessert is usually served at home for in large servings. This individual tart-like Clafoutis had a chewy texture and is very sweet. The prunes as well as the ice cream emit strong hints of rhum. Worth a try since it's not common in local French menus. Creme Brulee This is relatively large but I like generous portions of desserts since it is difficult to be satisfied with morsels of good things.A fairly decent brulee for the price. Grand Marnier SouffleThis mighty souffle rises to a level which is one the highest I have seen so far. The alcohol kick was satisfying but somehow I still miss a chocolate souffle. The sweet cream is really good because one can control the sweetness of the dessert. I recommend pouring everything in as it would taste quite eggy and plain on its own. Warm Chocolate Cake with Lavender Ice CreamThis molten cake is once again larger than the usual ones. The gooey inner filling oozes out as expected but it would be better if the outer cake wall was thinner. Otherwise there would be no more molten lava to go with the dry parts. Nonetheless, the lavender ice cream and creme anglaise did set this dish a little different from the rest. The lavender ice cream was particularly unique pairing and I appreciate it more than a vanilla scoop. The scent of lavender was quite strong which some might not be used to. Overall, the French meal here was a comfortable and cosy one without the occasion pressures of a fine-dining place. Moreover, the menu is not overpriced and has a variety of mains which include rabbit leg! The service staff were approachable and friendly.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: So good, I came for dinner two nights in a row.The first night was pretty busy, but thankfully the reservation held, and we were shown to our seats promptly. The Girlfriend was quite taken with the European-looking wait staff, and his (French?) accent, so looks like there were points there for authenticity. The fam joined us for night 2, and we had a lovely booth to ourselves.Food was not an easy pick - there is a lot to choose from, and almost all of it sounded lovely! Over the two nights, we had loads: the cassolette of escargot was super tasty, especially with the garlicky mushrooms; the mackerel fillet was light, and the accompaniments added great balance (thumbs up for the dressing!); the lamb rack, pork trotter, boeuf bourguigon, and roasted chicken leg? All of it disappeared.Some say dessert is the measure of a complete meal, and perhaps they need a bit more work here. We didn't enjoy these as much - the Grand Marnier Souffle packed too heavy a punch for me, while the ice nougat was a new experience, but not much to shout about. Perhaps the starters and mains had already blown our tastebuds away. The shining light was the homemade lavender ice cream - that really cleaned up the palate after some heavyweight mains, and was quite a delight to finish.Service did well by me and the fam too, Manager Jovy made her rounds, and the two fellas were engaging and polite as they navigated the dining room.They've just started a Sunday lunch menu, which promises a lot of family style food - right up my alley. Now, to round up the kinfolk...Oh and check for credit card promotions! No better way to round off a dining experience eh?

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Several friends had gushed about Taratata so when it came time for a girls' night out, F suggested we check out Taratata. The restaurant is cosy and the service is good so I was looking forward to trying the food.Had the pan fried duck foie gras with caramelised pears which was quite good followed by the grilled Angus rib eye with cognac black pepper sauce. Thought it was decent but thought the steak began to taste a bit bland halfway through, unlike certain places like Bedrock and Gordon Grill where the steak remains tasty throughout. F had the beef flank steak with shallot sauce and quite liked it. We skipped on dessert as we were too full.Wasn't blown away but might come back to try other dishes.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Was there during Restaurant Week so the value was really really good : $35++ for the whole meal, with a very good seared tuna first, then an okay salmon and a great apple crumble for dessert.Would definitely recommend it for a proper french bistrot dinner experience at a reasonable price (compared to fine dining), about S$150 for a dinner for two with some wine I would say.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: I've been wanting to try Taratata for awhile, as the menu looked promising.  It's classic French, and the restaurant enjoys a prime location on Keong Saik Road.  And inside, it looks like a classic bistro.  Stopped by for lunch earlier, and while the menu looked good, the execution was not as good.  I started off with French Onion soup which was ok, but the portion was quite small.  The main was a pork chop, but it was underseasoned, and the presentation was very underwhelming (see my photo).  And while they had a decent wine list, charging $30 for the cheapest red wine by the glass seems a bit too much, even in Singapore.  So overall, while the ambiance and menu hits the mark, the execution does not.  And with wine prices among the highest that I have encountered in Singapore, the price-value ratio isn't there either.

The atmosphere matters a lot too. Is the restaurant dirty, are there flies trying to attack your food? This is a nice restaurant, this is not a circus. If you want to be loud and obnoxious, go to the hawker center. We complained to one of the waitresses but she seemed too afraid to tell the next table to tone it down. We then told another waitress and she just smiled, as if she didn't understand us. Finally, we got so annoyed that we left. We told them we were leaving because of the noise and they still did nothing. I am going to talk about the food briefly, it is pity that the food was delicious yet we were not able to enjoy it. The cod was good. The cheese platter for desert was excellent- you get to choose your cheese from a cheese cart, which they do in France. The problem is that it was hard to hear the explanations about the different cheeses because of the obnoxious table next door. Bottom line: the waiters and waitresses should not be afraid to tell customers to be more considerate. If these customers are really drunk, do not be afraid to refuse to serve alcohol to them. (I am not sure if our table was drunk or not, but it is a possibility. Either way they were extremely loud.) It is a small restaurant, one loud table is enough to ruin the experience for everyone else. Either way I am not coming back. Just only because I don't spend over $130 per person on a meal but feel like I am in a hawker center.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Classic bistrot décor (with French music in the background) and classic bistrot food - nothing particularly innovative (so, for instance, no sweetbread or rabbit), just well-executed traditional brasserie dishes. We had the escargots, foie gras poêlé, entrecôte grillée, confit de canard, and tarte fine aux poires, and they're all yummy. Reasonable pricing; the set lunch represents great value. Decent wine list. Add to this friendly service. Fir sure, we will go back.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore

A good start already!We had escargot for starters - suffice to say, the other reviews on this page have it spot on. Typically the duck meat gets too dry or the skin is too soggy. I'm happy to share that they did this dish perfectly - the meat was moist, succulent and tender but the skin perfectly crispy and hot. Easily the best duck confit I've had in Singapore!Despite a slight hiccup in food service (our other order for main came 20 minutes late), the servers were at their best attending to us to make sure that we could share the duck confit (while we waited), and also gave us complimentary sorbet at the end of the night to make up for their mistakes. Like most good French places in Singapore, this place is not cheap (but not quite out of the stratosphere expensive). That said, good food, good wine and good service - I'm definitely coming back!

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Taratata Bistrot is a charming little French restaurant along Keong Saik Road which I've been meaning to try for sometime. I finally made time for it when i saw that it was on the Restaurant Week listing (yes i'm slow in updating) and it was only $25 for a 3 course meal. The prices are very reasonable even if you didn't make the RW bookings though. We were served starters from their regular menu, which is a good thing i feel. I hate it when restaurants serve a completely different (usually substandard) menu for RW. That kinda deters repeat visits especially if the food sucks.The Half Dozen of Snails Baked in Herbed Garlic Butter ($25). I found the escargots to be succulent and well flavored with garlic herbs. The Baked Eggs Casserole with Duck Gizzard Confit and Mushrooms ($24) had nice runny eggs that are best soaked up with the delicious baguette Taratata serves. Generous pieces of foie gras were swimming in the eggs but i thought they would be better seared first before thrown into the ramekin.Even though the mains were not from the regular menu, we were very happy with our dishes. The Salmon Coulibiac with Watercress Butter Sauce was lovely! The puff pastry was buttery and flaky and the salmon was cooked to a nice pink. The Pan Roasted Kurobuta Pork Tenderloin with Mustard sauce was done simply to allow diners a taste of the tender and non fatty meat. It's the first time i thought that pork could taste so clean and healthy. K thought it was a little too bland though.Dessert was the highlight of the meal! The Baked Chocolate Tart with Crisp, Caramel sauce and Ginger bread ice cream was out of this world. The crunchy tart held the intense chocolate lava and the pastry skin twirl made us twirly whirly in our seats as we devoured the dish without speaking (but we did make a lot of oooohs and aaaahhhhs. God they need to put this on their menu.Service was attentive and quick, maybe because they wanted us out fast for their second lunch service. If you're up for some quick lunch, Taratata Bistrot does a 40 minutes Lunch Express at $25 which includes a soup and a main course. For a more leisurely lunch, there's the $30 2-course set lunch and they also serve a 3 course set meal for $38. I'd recommend Taratata Bistrot for a charming and affordable French meal.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Perfect French bistrot, 2 French chefs, Bertrand and Philippe gave us a memorable classic and authentic French dinner.The lamb cutlets were so tasty, i found them better than some i had in a 3 stars michelin in France. A very nice cheese selection, reasonable and excellent wine list.Friendly and professional service.We will come back, we were back to France for few hours!!! Thank you.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: It was a great experience even though we skipped the mains and had 3 appetisers plus four desserts. French Onion SoupThis was done exactly the way I wanted it to be. Cheesy toast which was soaked in the savoury goodness. There was also some cheese crust that stuck stubbornly to the edges around the exterior pot that you should not waste. just use your hands to pluck them into your mouth. Once you dig in, there seemed to be endless amount of soft onions Escargots in herbed garlic and butterEscargots lovers must not miss this dish and it's recommended that you go for the dozen on the ala carte menu if you find that the 6 little ones on the sunday set menu insufficient to satisfy your craving. Crab and Pomelo SaladThis might not be commonly seen on French menu but it's certainly a refreshing starter to have. The crab meat hidden by the greens were fresh, sweet and creamy. Reminds me of a dense coleslaw without the vegetables. The pomelo was bitter but matched well with the crab. These 3 dishes were followed shortly by 4 desserts, which were mostly accompanied with a pot of creme anglaise. Prune Clafoutis with Rum and Raisin Ice creamThis was unexpectedly good as this French dessert is usually served at home for in large servings. This individual tart-like Clafoutis had a chewy texture and is very sweet. The prunes as well as the ice cream emit strong hints of rhum. Worth a try since it's not common in local French menus. Creme Brulee This is relatively large but I like generous portions of desserts since it is difficult to be satisfied with morsels of good things.A fairly decent brulee for the price. Grand Marnier SouffleThis mighty souffle rises to a level which is one the highest I have seen so far. The alcohol kick was satisfying but somehow I still miss a chocolate souffle. The sweet cream is really good because one can control the sweetness of the dessert. I recommend pouring everything in as it would taste quite eggy and plain on its own. Warm Chocolate Cake with Lavender Ice CreamThis molten cake is once again larger than the usual ones. The gooey inner filling oozes out as expected but it would be better if the outer cake wall was thinner. Otherwise there would be no more molten lava to go with the dry parts. Nonetheless, the lavender ice cream and creme anglaise did set this dish a little different from the rest. The lavender ice cream was particularly unique pairing and I appreciate it more than a vanilla scoop. The scent of lavender was quite strong which some might not be used to. Overall, the French meal here was a comfortable and cosy one without the occasion pressures of a fine-dining place. Moreover, the menu is not overpriced and has a variety of mains which include rabbit leg! The service staff were approachable and friendly.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: So good, I came for dinner two nights in a row.The first night was pretty busy, but thankfully the reservation held, and we were shown to our seats promptly. The Girlfriend was quite taken with the European-looking wait staff, and his (French?) accent, so looks like there were points there for authenticity. The fam joined us for night 2, and we had a lovely booth to ourselves.Food was not an easy pick - there is a lot to choose from, and almost all of it sounded lovely! Over the two nights, we had loads: the cassolette of escargot was super tasty, especially with the garlicky mushrooms; the mackerel fillet was light, and the accompaniments added great balance (thumbs up for the dressing!); the lamb rack, pork trotter, boeuf bourguigon, and roasted chicken leg? All of it disappeared.Some say dessert is the measure of a complete meal, and perhaps they need a bit more work here. We didn't enjoy these as much - the Grand Marnier Souffle packed too heavy a punch for me, while the ice nougat was a new experience, but not much to shout about. Perhaps the starters and mains had already blown our tastebuds away. The shining light was the homemade lavender ice cream - that really cleaned up the palate after some heavyweight mains, and was quite a delight to finish.Service did well by me and the fam too, Manager Jovy made her rounds, and the two fellas were engaging and polite as they navigated the dining room.They've just started a Sunday lunch menu, which promises a lot of family style food - right up my alley. Now, to round up the kinfolk...Oh and check for credit card promotions! No better way to round off a dining experience eh?

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Several friends had gushed about Taratata so when it came time for a girls' night out, F suggested we check out Taratata. The restaurant is cosy and the service is good so I was looking forward to trying the food.Had the pan fried duck foie gras with caramelised pears which was quite good followed by the grilled Angus rib eye with cognac black pepper sauce. Thought it was decent but thought the steak began to taste a bit bland halfway through, unlike certain places like Bedrock and Gordon Grill where the steak remains tasty throughout. F had the beef flank steak with shallot sauce and quite liked it. We skipped on dessert as we were too full.Wasn't blown away but might come back to try other dishes.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Where to begin. I'll start with the food. Overall it was pretty good. The french onion soup was awesome. Not the best I ever had which was almost orgasmic but this was very tasty. Couldve used a little more cheese but oh well.  My cassoulet was pretty good. I had never had one before so dont know what to compare it to. I wouldnt say the flavor was jumping in my mouth but it was a good dish.  The dessert was a great warm chocolate cake with loads of chocolate oozing out.  The wine was good and the ambiance was nice and relaxed. A good spot for a date. I have mixed feelings about this restaurant though.  I dont want to be jaded by maybe what was a bad night for them. But I thought the service was sub par.  I felt the manager was great and attentive. She gave great recommendations and was working hard. I felt like she was running the whole restaurant. I dont know what the other servers were doing. It took 20 min to process our credit cards and we were the only ones left in the restaurant. Its too bad because everything else was really nice.  Like I said, maybe it was a bad night for them. If you enjoy french cuisine I'd try it for sure.

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: I was brought on a date the first time, and I was rather charmed by the bistro setting that definitely reminded me of my stay in Paris not  too long ago. The waiters were all dressed up and the warm lighting inside with tables tightly packed were quintessentially Parisian. The menu did not disappoint. Good old classics like Coq Au Vin, Confit de Canard, Escargots and Soupe a l'Oignon got me excited. The mackerel salad had caught my eye as I remember a rather delicious variant when I was visiting the French Countryside. I went with that, as well as the Poulet Rotî ( Orast Chicken) for my main course.The Mackerel Fillet marinated in white wine with scented potatoes salad had been so stunning, that was all I could think of since then. The perfumed salad had a light floral and earthy taste, possibly the doing of a herb infused oil. The fish was not the least fishy and it was delicate and soft, marrying perfectly with the potatoes that were lightly dressed. The greens and garnishing herbs were light in flavour not too overpowering, lending a great touch to the delicate textures of the dish. The main course were impressive, enough to leave an impression and a longing to be back.I manage to catch a glimpse of the lunch menu that seemed very economical at just $30 for three course. This is cheaper than the usual lunch set menus in Parisian bistro and with the quality of the dinner there, I am sure to go back to try their lunch!

address: 35A Keong Saik Rd Ground Floor Singapore 089142 Singapore
comment: Nice Ambience and excellent & attentive service.  Classic dishes done right - Escargot, French Onion Soup and Creme Brûlée.  Worth a try - good for dinner party or a quiet date.  The set dinner menu was good value for money.  On a very happening street.

rest_name: Jim Garden 珍厨明苑私房菜
comment: The restaurant opened recently in Tanjong Pagar. It originated from an award winning restaurant in mainland China. The restaurant offered private home cuisine 私房菜 , without the usual seasonings such as MSG, salt and castor sugar. Although small in size, the restaurant offered well priced dishes.This month the restaurant is having a lunch promotion with Gold Medal Pork Rib with Pineapple Rice 金牌西菠排骨饭 at S$3.80, instead of usual S$7.60.- Limited to first 50 dine in customers everyday.The soya bean milk offered here had an acquired taste especially for the unsweetened version. It's known as Five Flavours of Soy Milk 招牌五味濃縮豆漿 (S$2.80), as it's made of soya bean, red bean, green bean, black bean, and peanut.Sautéed Tender Meat with Black Fungus 葱香梅肉炒秋耳 (S$14.80/ large, S$11.80/ small)Simple looking dish but the sliced meat was tender with the black fungus giving a crunch to the dish.Braised Tofu in Special Sauce 風味醬燜豆腐 (S$11.80/ large, S$8.80/ small)Simple looking dish but the tofu was very smooth.Gold Medal  Pork Rib with Pineapple  金牌西菠排骨 (S$28)The meat was fork tender, easily tearing off from the bones. Sweet & Sour Seabass 糖醋金目鱸魚  (S$32)Interestingly orange juice, dragon fruit and other assorted fruits were used to make the sauce for the dish, instead of the usual vinegar, which was why some customers may felt that the flavours may be not as strong as expected.
