This is my favorite cheap eat in Singapore. No other nasi lemak has compared.Make sure to get the coconut rice. Every topping I had was excellent with the vegetables being especially great. The combo I got cost me S$3.50. What a steal!

Previously hawkering its wares at the foot of Mount Faber in Telok Blangah, the stall is now at Chinatown round the corner from Restaurant Ember and Burnt Ends. There's a hodgepodge of side dishes, apart from the usual fried egg, ikan bilis, and fried fish accompaniments. Get the:1) cabbage curry2) fried chicken wing3) luncheon meat ($5)4) Chicken currySkip the:5) Fried egg6) scrambled eggs with onions; these were overcooked and rubberyThe rice was intoxicatingly fragrant but delicate in flavour. I would have preferred it more flavourful. That said, the grains were fluffy and plump, but not slicked with oil, which was a big plus.Get the sambal as well, it's free flow, and lends a punchy heat to the rice.

Don't let the 'Mount Faber' in its name confuse you; this eatery is actually in Chinatown and, boy, is it a fantastic find. They have a large variety of dishes to choose from to heap atop their fragrant, rich rice, ranging from fried chicken wings to a multitude of vegetarian options. The staff always ask if you would like to have white rice or nasi lemak, and I strongly recommend that you go for the latter because it truly is a treat. I usually have their curry vegetables, ikan billis and otah, more often than not freshly grilled. Heap on their homemade chilli and you've got yourself a pretty awesome combination. They stay open till late, which makes this a great supper destination for those in the neighbourhood. We all know how difficult it can be to find a cab home from Chinatown on weekend nights these days, and stumbling upon Mount Faber makes being stranded far less vexing.

Good things come in small packages. This hidden gem hosts beautiful decor, a small but solid menu, and a laid back vibe.  Yes, it has a hipster vibe, but is also very minimalist (think gray and beige) with succulents scattered throughout.The foodThe nam ban bao is the standout here.  A perfectly fried piece of tender chicken is nestled between the fluffy bao for a few perfect bites.  The salted egg yolk shrimp had a nice crunch, but could have used a little more seasoning.  The pork belly brings me back to traditional braised pork belly I loved as a kid.  It's served au jus style with a side of stock!  The truffle fries were wonderfully salty here too.I'd definitely return for the good vibes, relaxed atmosphere and good food.

This place was really awesome!! Great ambiance, and amazing bao. We were craving bao on our trip and found it online and absolutely were not disappointed. We tried 6 different bao and loved all of them--my favorite was the crab! Also in a fun part of Chinatown so you can grab drinks after dinner.

Such a cute little spot on Horne Road. I appreciate that they focus on giving baos a bit of a twist.The baos are all Asian inspired, with flavours like bulgogi, salted egg shrimp, and teriyaki chicken. I stuck with the classic (slow-braised pork belly) and the nanban chicken, which was a deep fried chicken with Japanese tartar sauce.The classic had all the right flavours involved, however I found the meat a tad dry. I still think Ubin Kitchen on Joo Chiat Road holds the title for best classic bao in SG! I really liked the nanban chicken, though- perfectly deep fried and the sauce paired well.Ambiance is simple, though it can get a bit loud and echo-y when there's a lot of people. Other than that, a cute cafe worth checking out if you're looking for something a little different!

I actually really like this place, despite my distaste for most hipster things in Singapore these days. They take reservations online, accept credit cards, have great service, and free wifi.Food-wise... I got two buns; the salted egg shrimp and the nanban along with a side of salad. Gosh! I LOVE the nanban. Freshly fried with some lettuce within, with an awesome tartar sauce. I should have gotten two nanbunsss. The salted egg shrimp was okay - could have been better if the shrimp was deep fried and the sauce could actually coat the shrimp, instead of dripping everywhere. The bun itself was soft and slightly sweet. Yum!I finished off with a banana walnut sundae, quite delish. Would return.

The Bao Makers took over the colourful Windowsill Pies shop that moved to Upper Thomson. Instead of keeping the similar type of decoration, the Bao Makers stripped everything to white. From the outside the café stood out quite well due to the colour. On the inside, they also kept the minimalistic industrial look with the cemented walls and wooden furnitures, perfect for hipsters to hangout. We visited the Bao Makers on the last day of our holiday when we were quite full from our previous dinner, but at the back of my mind I always remembered my conversation with Em that I'd go and try the bao at this place. So without further contemplation I dragged hubby in and ordered two baos, the chili crab and Korean bulgogi pork. I like both but the succulent and spicy chili crab definitely delivered more flavour especially with the crispy golden bao. I really like the idea of infusing the local dish into the bao, something that I never seen before at other places. The filling for both baos were sufficient. Since Hubby was craving for dessert he also ordered a pretty serving of lemon meringue sundae. The meringue came as the topping in the shape of rose, the rest of the ingredients were lemon sponge, lemon curd and vanilla ice cream with almond slices. It was delicious but a bit awkward to be called a sundae except if you break the meringue and the sponge cake, then mix the whole thing together with the ice cream.  We had a good time at the Bao Makers and we hope they will be a one stop shop for bao and able to come up with a lot of different fillings next time we go to Singapore.

Nice space but average food. A 2.5 stars review.The baos are tiny for the prices that they are charging - about $5.50 for one depending on the fillings. You'll need  at least 2 to fill you up (they also require a min of 2 baos per order). So a meal here will set you up for more than $10. Aside from the price, the taste doesn't quite make the cut. While the nanban chicken (fried chicken) is nicely fried and served out piping hot and crispy, the marinate on the chicken doesn't come through and there is also too much mayo with the tiny piece of chicken.The chilli crab bun is a take on a Singaporean favorite. While it is full of real shredded crabs, the accompanying sauce is a diluted chilli liquid that has nothing of the usual eggy crabby gravy of a good chilli crab sauce. Place is typically hipster with nice simple decor but the taste and value of the food is not enough to bring me back.

As I rarely come to this area, I have no idea the existence of this cafe, thanks to Natalie. From Lavender MRT station, the walk takes around 10 minutes, but do bring an umbrella if the weather forecast is rain as there is no shelter for most parts of the walk: When I think of 'Bao' (Chinese bread), I expect a Chinese style cafe or something like that but when I entered the cafe, it was different from what I expected. I didn't read the review or find out about more this cafe as I wanted to get an element of surprise and I did! The cafe is quite spacious as there is good amount of privacy between you and the other customers. If you are in a big group (around 6-10), you be pleased to know there is a Long table and if needed, they just add a table or two. Perfect for some catching up as its quiet and not crowded for most of the time, according to another Yelper. Orders are self service and free wifi is available but you have to ask the staff for the password. It would be nice if they could leave the password either on the table or on the receipt. Staff were friendly and more importantly no sign of impatience or pressure to leave the cafe even though the group had finish the food for quite some time and got lost in the wonderful conversation. I ordered the Namban Chicken and Classic (check my photo of the menu for more information) and I find them to be my liking for my taste bud. Not the best but decent enough for me to make another trip back to try out the other flavours. Prices is reasonable and portion is definitely value for money. Overall, this is a great cafe for catching up and enjoying the "bao"! Do drop by if you are nearby or have a craving for "Bao".

Ambience is chic and hip. Love the mix of raw cement walls and wooden floors. Interesting menu although the helping size seems a tad small. The lobster roll and salted egg shrimp Bao were better than the seafood carbonara. The shake mentaiko rice bowl met with immediate approval complete with the onsen egg!

My new favorite neighborhood spot. I love places that just make a few things but do them well. The Nanban Chicken bao was my favorite. The chicken is juicy, and the skin perfectly crispy and light, and the Japanese tartar sauce is just right. My wife had the classic pork belly and salted egg shrimp bao, which were also both excellent but not quite as good as the chicken for my taste. Lastly, their truffle fries were a bit on the salty side, but full of cheesy truffley goodness. Besides the food, the decor is right up my alley. Clean and modern, wide open spaces and gray and brown accents. Service was super fast, which is another big plus with places that have small menus. We had our bao in less than five minutes after ordering, which is great for a case of mid-afternoon munchies.

clean and open concept cafe. Finally a cafe where there is actually space and i don't feel claustrophobic. Headed straight in. Ordered an Ice- Latte to start, 5 minutes later its done and i have to say its really pretty good. Being at a Bao place. You've got to try the baos right? so i went straight for the shrimp with salted egg yolk one. The bummer was that it was a minimum order of 2 baos, and i really had wanted to sit down and relax and not stuff myself with 2 baos. But i understand the procedure as steaming just one bao would be quite a waste of steam i suppose. so i had to go for the traditional one. The classic "kong bak" bao/pork belly. The shrimp one could do with a more stronger salted egg yolk sauce, but all in all, the shrimp was fresh and crisp. As for the pork belly bao, it would be nice if it had a thicker sauce around the meat. The staff here are friendly and would go the extra mile to help. So the next time you're around horne road or going to catch a soccer match at the jalan besar stadium. Come over and get yourself a great cup of coffee and some baos. A great place for an afternoon snack, brunch or a light dinner.

Try the tasting menu here : 1. It's good value 2. U experience the full creativity of the chefs Have been coming to this bistro more than once and love the chef's interpretation of fusion food. So creative and so delightful !Remember to bring cash or your nets card !

While waiting for my friend to be done with work, decided to come here as her office was located opposite this store.Came here the second time before writing in this review. The first time I came, I had savory bread - Bacon Focaccia. It looked good on the display section and it was even better after they used the oven to heat it up. It was also filling and I just had one piece of that for dinner. When I was about to leave, I bought the lemon meringue. It wasn't as good as I thought it will be as I consumed it hours later. The second time I came, I had the Raspberry Croissant. The server also heat it up before serving. I asked for a to go bag (brown bag) so that I am able to taste the croissant in bites instead of using fork and knife. The raspberry filling was so amazing. On top of the croissant there were powdered sugar and almond which made it sweet and crunchy. The texture of the flakes was just done perfectly. Service was excellent. The servers will repeat the order of what you are getting one more time for accuracy. They also greet you upon entering this cafe. Every time I come here, people also started to rush inside here to buy other kinds of breads or pastries. They also serve main courses as well as soups. Definitely a good place to hang out during the rainy days or during tea time. Will be back for more soon :)

Small café on Keong Saik road (home to one of the highest concentration of great eateries in the city), which serves up some of the freshest baked goods around. We tried the rum and raisin croissant with their iced lemon tea and a cappuccino (small order because we were waiting for our turn for lunch at a nearby place). The coffee was really good, lemon tea was very refreshing and the flaky pastry reminded me of Paris. Ah well, we can't travel now, so have to travel via food. I'll be back to try more of their baked goods for sure!

Small cafe that bakes a wide variety of bread every day. I tried the croissant  (plain), the baguette, and an Americano. All were tasty, but I would say the baguette was most impressive especially because I had it when it had just come out of the oven  (still warm)! Seating here is limited and the tables and stools are small. Best for solo or duo seating.  Terrible place to come with a large group.The employees were very friendly and helpful and I liked their music selection too. Would come back again next time I'm in the area!

Almond croissant ($3.50) - 2.5 starsI suppose I was eating it right after lunch... But honestly it was nothing special - not much almond filling. They even warmed it up. Probably wouldn't get it again.Ambience - 3 starsClean but tables are small. I got my croissant to go.

I was staying down the road and craving some food in the evening, but I felt too lazy to walk far or actually sit down at a restaurant, so I happened upon Bread & Hearth. I had asked for something that they didn't have because it was so close to closing time, so I chose a ham and cheese bread and a focaccia instead. They were delicious! They warmed up the food for me to take back to my hotel, and I also got a free croissant because I had bought 2 breads. Everything was absolutely delicious and the service was prompt and friendly.
Good pastries and a great basic latte here. After pastries stayed for seconds of a bacon ham and cheese on bread.  Small place with good service on the late Sunday we were there.
Delicious food and great service! I would definitely recommend visiting for breakfast!
Excellent café with artisanal bread and pastries. So far the best Americano in Singapore and the almond croissant could had been made in France. Highly recommended!
This is a cute place that serves amazing pastries at affordable prices (chocolate croissants at $3, cinnamon rolls about the same). Coffee is also good. Highly rate the sandwiches as well

Raspberry croissant is buttery, crunchy and not too sweet with the light raspberry filling. I thought it was delicious. You can smell the baked goods from a few steps away. The place is small and cozy, does have a feel of a bakery with tables so it's easy to grab a fresh pastry or bread with a coffee and enjoy the ambiance in air con.

You have my heart at baked anything, and i can never say no to freshly baked breads, pastries, cakes, you name it. It's the smell of butter and sugar probably, both of which i cannot resist and that resulted in a shopping spree when i stumbled into Bread and Hearth, a new artisanal bakery in the Keong Saik/ Chinatown/ Ann Siang area. Bread and Hearth prides themselves with using pure butter and quality ingredient. There is absolutely no shortening used, as highlighted by the friendly staff. French Normandy butter and flour goes into making these quality pastries.The Matcha Orange is a bread roll with a nice matcha fragrance and the flavor is lifted by the refreshing chunky orange peel. The Honey Chocolate bread ($3) was porous and very bouncy. Even though it said Honey Chocolat, it wasn't sweet at all and it actually had a salty taste. That said, i still like how it was flavored nicely with the dark chocolate chip bits. Do add some honey to it after you toast it. I swear it's divine.The Bacon Focaccia ($6.50) is exactly that kinda bread that i'd want for a breakfast. The fragrance was taunting me during work the whole afternoon and i finally succumbed to my weakness and took several bites and boy was it satisfying. It's the perfect savory snack. I would eat the foccacia even if it didn't have bacon on it. The Cream Cheese Sesame ($2.80) turned out to be a sweet treat instead of a savory one! Think dense creamy cheese with a nice sweet pastry crust peppered with smokey sesame seeds. Yummy! Another must try is the Bostock which is more than 50% cake i swear. Bread and Hearth also does sandwiches and coffee and they do have a nice enough spot for lunch/tea.

Good breakfast venue to start a day. Breakfast plate, including scramble egg, simple salad, juicy sausages and croissant with coffee is bit too much volume. I prefer simple combination of croissant and long black. Long black is quite good.
Lovely bakery. I'm definitely smitten by their pain au chocolate. Sandwiches are decent, burger is overrated. The show stoppers are what they pull out of the oven.

Cute little bakery that has all sorts of pastries and sandwiches.  I had a very good croissant sandwich and vanilla latte - it was teeny tiny and coat $7 but I enjoyed it and bought another a few days later.

I have only tried the almond croissant, sliced bread and latte here but this three items have won me over! I cannot wait to try the other pastries at bread and hearth. And a bonus, the staff here are super helpful and nice!

the 3 of us went here for breakfast. small menu but good for a quick quality bite. café latte was good and the croque monsieur tasty. fresh orange juice at SGD$3. great! the bacon sandwich was also good. the baquette was crispy and fresh with butter and jam, simple but great! the raspberry croissant was a bit different and worth to try.

Our second visit and this time we have reinforcement. We ordered the grouper fish steamboat, the fried prawn roll and a stir fried Nai Bai vegetable. The steamboat is really good. They use red grouper which is more tasty than the black ones. The fish is fresh and we ordered the fish head instead of the fish slices. The broth is tasty with mixed vegetables. The Buddha's delight that we had previously was a bit salty so this time we opt for the stir fried nai bai. The Buddha's delight are precooked and they just reheat when order is received. The air fried dishes are cooked when ordered so you can request for some variation. I would come back for the steamboat but not the others. With a steamboat and some rice or noodles it makes a complete meal.

oh how i miss andre!:(coming back here, where restaurant andre used to be, brought back great memories and thus anticipation of yet another gastronomic adventure.it's akin to being reacquainted with an ex girlfriend that you did not have closure with. not sure why she left in the first place and not sure what to expect now that she is back but in a different form?the familiarity of the layout is comforting, recognizing some of andre's previous staff is reassuring.the concept of restaurant zen however is uniquely different.you still have the kitchen on the ground floor but this is where your culinary journey actually starts and you linger here till you finish your ordering, start imbibing in drinks, get introduced to the produce you will consume and be warmly welcomed with savoury snackings.an excellent selection of artisanal gin is available and that distracted me from their comprehensive wine list.the standout snacking dish for me at the kitchen has to be the vendace roe from Kalix "Raraka"(Sweden), you can view the photo(s) when uploaded and salivate.then you proceed upstairs to the dining room.the music is much louder and funkier than what i am used to when fine dining.but the vintage of some songs brought a smile or two.every course is well paced and "prepared" right by your table.witnessing the finishing touches, plating, combined with proximate interaction with the chefs made for a more complete experience.for those teetotaller, the non alcoholic pairing might brighten your evening and even just a sampling or two was game changing and they actually look like you are consuming alcohol too, lol.standout dishes on this floor has to be the blue lobster, crispy Koshihikari rice, yuzu pepper, clarified butter emulsion & sansho leaf.the scallop with white truffle left a lasting impression too but alas i heard it may not make the menu again when they seasonally change it in the near future.as for the dry aged Miyazaki A5 wagyu beef, it had me at reading the menu.as if those dishes were not enough, you are ushered to the next level, the living room.here you get your coffee, tea or........plus dessert!those with sweet tooth can rejoice but i had much rather descend to the kitchen and/or dining room for seconds.finally, as you are ready to leave, you take the lift back down(because you just can't walk anymore after gaining at least 5kgs) to the kitchen and get a good pow wow send off from everyone awaiting.yes, i still miss andre.it's just not the same.it's me, not you.

I am not sure the restaurant is called that anymore but even if, it is a good place to come to for a good local food experience in a very simple setting.They also feature the famed Singaporean fish head soup which I'll probably try some day.We had soup with white fish fillet and Seafood Noodles (especially made for me as I did not like to have the pork with which it was featured in the menu).You get fresh chilli with your meal, collect your drinks inside, pay for them and then pay for your meal order directly at the table.The food came pretty fast and was very nice indeed, good portions and taste for 10 S$. We'll certainly be back.

I am normally a very tough "grader" but this place deserves a lot of credit because it is one of the few authentic Chinese places in Tiong Bahru. This also implies that it is not overpriced and popular. A couple of taxi drivers told me that this was one of the best Congee places in town (congee=porridge) and I concur. I am not a Congee expert but I had, for my third visit, a pork congee with century egg and it was lovely.A solid choice!

The place is in an open-air coffee shop in the hip burb of Tiong Bahru. The type of congee here is not my favorite; and I also think the bowls here are a bit small, as I like giant steaming bowls of congee. The congee is cooked in a home style, where the rice is not super smooth like the Cantonese restaurant sort. It does do the trick if you're in a congee fix.The salmon yusheng was okay. Would return if I didn't know what to eat in the area.

It is a rustic outdoor eatery. Lots of people eating. The congee was pretty good. Just stick with the congee. Make sure you are immune to street food. Don't bother with extra garnish because they aren't particularly "clean" or "hygienic". Everything else was not that great. The youtiao was stale. The deep fried tofu was refried. The veggies were soggy and too salty.

Rustic porridge cooked over charcoal is their main selling point. The porridge itself not much taste despite the dark looking sauce. So copious amounts of additional soy sauce had to be added. I like that you can get more ginger and spring onions as well.

Had it once sometime back. Wanted to go back again. Could not find the place anymore :( that is, until two weeks ago :) Simple - the way a bowl of porridge is suppose to be. Menu is classified to the type of "meat" that you want in. Add an egg? Without an egg? Your choice. Sides of smoked duck or fried dumpling? Both are not that interesting so just stick to the good old fashion porridge :)

Just like bak kut teh, porridge is another one of those dishes where I'm all, "Why the hell would anyone eat this when it's hot enough to fry an egg on the sidewalk?!" But being someone who's open to trying new things, I figured I might as well see what the fuss is about.Ah Chiang's has been around for decades, but I'll leave it to the reviews below to talk about its history. When I visited during my lunch break, the place was hopping with locals, both professionals and those who are retired and probably live around the block. Since it's difficult to find a table during peak lunch hour, my colleagues and I did a takeaway order this time around.  The aunties that run the cashier can be a bit brusque, but don't take it personally. Also, if you do takeaway, don't take it personally when they call a number, you know it's not your order, but then they glare at you thinking it is your order, and then when you prove to them it isn't, they start yelling amongst themselves trying to figure out whether a guest isn't listening or if someone on the staff is an idiot for taking the wrong order.I decided to play it safe by just ordering the plain pork porridge (I think it's the 2nd or 3rd one on the menu) which doesn't include intestines, liver or anything your typical Westerner wouldn't eat. Once I got back to the office and tried it (in an air conditioned environment) I didn't think it was half bad. I will have to echo the other reviews in that it is pretty plain, so it's best to take my colleague's advice of adding soy sauce, ginger, and pepper for more taste.However, the price can't be beat. If you include the extra charge for takeaway, it came out to $4.25, and I was unable to finish my bowl.

I only had the fish congee. What a disappointment. The congee is very bland. It gets flavor/seasoning from the soy sauce. You just mix that into the bland congee to give it some taste. Anyone can cook this.

Tried the frog porridge here, which was ok. The pieces were quite small and bony. Don't think this is exactly the place to go for frog porridge. Better to go for some of the other comfort porridge dishes.

Came here for the first time when my boss decided that it was time for breakfast and was instantly converted into a fan! Prior to visiting this place, porridge wasn't something that would come to mind for a meal (distant memories of childhood and being force fed plain porridge still haunt me) but this changed everything. I've returned for 2 times and counting ever since!One of my colleagues and I always order their pork balls porridge, which is THE BEST of the lot. Also, chinese sashimi (raw fish) is a pretty acquired taste and way more fishy than the Japanese version but the thin slithers of raw fish in soy sauce were good and went well with the porridge! Go for the more expensive version if you can though. We also had some fried fish skin once, which was very salty on its own but nice when eaten alternately with porridge.(I daresay that this place actually rivals the more popular Zhen Zhen porridge at Maxwell... probably my favourite porridge place in Singapore at the moment)Haven't been here for awhile as my workplace has changed but I'll come back here regularly when I'm posted for work near the area!
Very nice staff and service. Perfectly cooked porridge. Can't miss the fried tofu with chilli sauce.

I've had Ah Chiang's more times than I can count now, mainly because I used to and currently work within walking distance and it was my late lunch eatery of choice (the other places sell out).They serve up porridge with almost any combination of ingredients you'd like, and personally I always go for the minced pork and shredded chicken porridge with an egg. Add extra soy sauce, smother it in pepper, and you're good to go.They're also really popular for their other dishes like their tofu in Thai-like chili sauce, their raw fish (that I confess I've never dared to try), and a few other things that I've noticed other people ordering but never really felt like indulging.The porridge though is solid. It's hearty, nourishing, and when hot, thick. Once it cools down it does get kinda watery, so do try to eat it fast for maximum enjoyment. Taking away costs extra, but gives the raw egg a little extra time to cook (as long as you're not carrying it too far away) for that perfect soft boiled consistency.The soya milk is a bit on the overly sweet side, so I don't really recommend it... but if you like sweet then. Well.

Ah Chiang's Porridge is a traditional no-frills porridge stall that's been around since the 70s. They serve it in the Cantonese style of thick comforting gruel with your choice of pork / fish / abalone etc. There are also sides of century eggs, platters of thinly sliced raw fish and fried tofu. The porridge itself errs a bit of the side of tasteless although the texture and consistency is pretty good. They also serve regular and almond tau huay in the Lao Ban pudding style, so those who don't fancy the long queues at Lao Ban might do well to have a bowl or three here.Service is fairly efficient.

Was suppose to be good porridge but I thought it tasted like any other porridge joint.  I still will never understand how people eat porridge in the Singapore heat (we had ours for take away).  I would get it if I were in the neighborhood but would not make my way there just to eat it.
Yummy porridge could have been better with a bigger portion and if they close slightly later to cater to all the people around the area!
Good place to get a bowl of porridge. Only Singaporean will eat this porridge in hot and humid weather sitting outdoor, because the porridge is healthy, tasty. Shiok!
Excellent coffee. Food is also solid. Even in a big group, everyone can find something to order. No complaints from anyone either. Except on the pricey side. Lines on the weekend, weekdays are fine

Got the opening time wrong so got here at 8:30am on a Sunday.  As soon as the door opens at 9, the restaurant fills up rather quickly.  We got the Lamb Eggs, Avocado Toast with a Waldorf.  Service staff very smiley and friendly.  Even brought extra plates without asking!!! Now that is service!! Nice interior clean setup.  Downside $1 for water. Pork Sausage wonderfully done and tasted spectacular.  In terms of value for money think common man would fair better.

Booked the place for Christmas eve dinner and the restaurant was having Sunday Roast Dinner. There was 3 different dining slots for dinner. I selected the earliest which was 5.30pm and the 2 of us were given the kitchen counter seats where we had a great view of happening in the busy place. Sitting next to us was the head chef's mother who shared with us who was visiting Singapore. Watching the kitchen, I realized the roasted turkey was faster than one usually expected.We started the meal with Pork Terrine (S$15++)Served with homemade pickles and clementine jamThe light crispy toaste, spread with the chunky terrine, and topped with some pickles such as onion, and beetroot, quite peaked up the appetite. Beetroot & Gin Cured Salmon (S$15++)Served with cucumber potato salad and herb mayonnaiseThe salmon tasted just like sashimi that one would not felt that it was cured version.The meal was followed by huge serving of main courses. Roast Beef  (S$25++)Served with sides of red cabbage, buttered green beans, duck fat fried potato, and bread sauceWhile the meat looked rather raw, it sliced easily and tasted delicious. The sides were good too, except for the bread sauce which one felt it was too starchy.Roast Turkey ( S$25++)Served with sides of red cabbage, buttered green beans, mashed potatoes , and gravyOne would thought that the meat would be rather tough and dry, but the version here was kind of juicy and went quite well with the light but flavourful gravy. Topped up with the well braised slightly sweet cabbage, it tasted even better.Accompanied with Christmas stuffing (S$3++)Pork mince, pine nuts and thyme.I was not a fan of christmas stuffing as I always felt it was rather strong in herbs taste. The version was more like meat loaf with a bit of nutty texture.Ended the meal with a couple of Christmas cookies topped with cream cheese topping, complimentary from the chef.

Nice location within around 6 mins walk from Outram Park MRT. The food and coffee here is okay. I like the atmosphere of the coffee shop with colorful decorations. It's a nice place to meet friends, it's quiet, the closing time is quite early though (I went there on Monday..).

I called up around 12.20pm on a Sunday and they said it was a 15-20 min wait. When I got there about 30 min later the queue system said it would be a 15-30 min wait. It ended up being a 45 min wait! Honestly, I don't think it's worth a 45 min wait.The Lokal Beef Burger ($25++ = $29.25) - 3.5 starsPretty good but there was quite a bit of fat in the patty and the burger wasn't special - cheddar, tomato sauce, vegetables. I got salad instead of the fries so can't comment on the fries. Good portion.Soy Chai Latte ($6 + $1 iced + $1 soy = $8++) - 3.5 starsExpensive!Roast Pumpkin Salad ($18 + $8 for smoked salmon) - 4 starsMy friend enjoyed this!Red Berry Smoothie ($10) - 2.5 starsWe decided we could make it at home.Even after the Entertainer app, it ended up being $55 for 2 mains and 2 drinks. Guess it's the GST and service charge.Service - 5 starsShout out to Satia! Other staff were great too.

Chanced upon this cafe along Neil Road. Managed to get a table quite fast even though there was queue. The pork burger, muesli and eggs were surprisingly good but the place was too pricey for us. One visit was enough.

We waited for close to 45 mins for a 2 seats on a Saturday around 1+, so it might be a good idea to reserve seats before coming on a crowded weekend! The were benches outside for waiting and an organised queue system which eased the wait. We had the banana bread ($15) which had been widely raved about by many bloggers and cafe goers. The bread was soft and moist and paired well with the yogurt and nuts, but was nothing extraordinary and was a bit steep for its price tag of $15. A plus point would be that it was not too sweet and hence rather easy on the palate. For dessert, the sticky date pudding was a pleasant end to the meal. In fact, I'd say skip the banana bread and have this instead. The sticky date pudding pairs well with the vanilla bean ice cream and the degree of sweetness depends on the amount of syrup you choose to dip your pudding in. Warm and sweet, it'd definitely satisfy those with a sweet tooth!The coffee was particularly disappointing. With beans from sarnies, it failed to provide the kick the usual Joe from sarnies does and lacked depth. It was also rather acidic with a distinct difference between the milk and espresso, failing to come together as a whole.Overall, a nice place to try if you're in the area, but personally not worth the wait given it's higher price tag and the availability of better options in the vicinity.

Let it be known that the lobster roll is a SLIPPER lobster roll. Big difference and to be fair, it does say so in the menu description but still, the dish is called a lobster roll. Hrrm. It was greatly disappointing. Overall it's too big and there's too little slipper lobster. It's about 80% purple slaw and 20% slipper lobster. Just imagine getting slipper lobster 1 in every 5 bites. The slipper lobster was kind of tasteless and the roll was too huge and just a glorified hotdog bun. The handcut fries were excellent, though one wouldn't come back just for the fries, would one.

Thoroughly disappointing. The evening kicked off with the service staff's recommendation of a light, easy-to-drink red wine that was overly chilled and truly awful. Tasted like the watered down juice you sometimes get when they run out of Welch's grape juice on Communion Sunday. Thankfully, they made good with a couple of glasses of another mediocre wine which were drinkable but also over-refrigerated and  unimpressive. Perhaps the bottled ciders might do better. The food was also painfully mediocre. Marco Pierre White once said that generosity is the greatest garnish. I don't think we had any Marco fans in the house and I feel like they don't like salt either. Under-seasoned, uninspired. Needless to say, I'm not going back.

A 4.5 review (cannot seem to add the extra 1/2!). Excellent service- friendly and prompt. Real cold drip coffee! Ciabatta Chicken was really yum and the Smashed Avo, Ricotta on Sourdough I am told was fabulous. Great vibe for Friday lunch.

Just attended my 3rd UYE ...... Nice cozy place and ambience ...... a few of us attended this event ..... The menu is not extensive and it's seems limited food to order ..... Had a great time chatting with fellow yelppers. The plus point thing about the food here is that you can do your own breakfast style with the breakfast sides.Seriously if you ask me ..... I didn't feel great after I finish my breakfast. I build my own breakfast and i ordered sauteed mushroom, smoked salmon, poched egg and sourdough bread and wild berries smoothie to quench my thirst. The presentation of the food is not fantastic as it was separated into two plates upon serving.The mushroom, poached egg and smoked salmon is nice but the sourdough bread is toasted hard to consumed. The bacon is cook hard too and it taste plain.The smoothie doesn't taste fruity or neither it taste berry ...... It's simply not the best that I ever had ...... Overall this would be my last trip

It was a Wednesday evening, standing along Neil Road, my friends and I were trying to locate the cafe. Though the entrance was huge, somehow we couldn't see it. The three of us stood outside Gothe Institut scratching our heads, where's The Lokal?A quick phone call and one of the service staff came out to "pick us". Somehow the diagonal entrance escaped our eyes. Walking into the cafe, it was fairly empty. At around 7pm, there were only 2 tables filled. The full fledged bar welcomes us as we entered then the open kitchen at the back. As we had made reservations, we were seated where the nice cushion seats were. Tucked in a cosy corner, it was the perfect place for 3 girls to hangout and share our hearts out.The menu came and we were told that the mains & appetizers are changed regularly. Since we decided on a side of truffle chips, we gave the appetizers a miss and ordered our mains. Recommendations from the service staff were the pork belly with Apple sauce and lamb shank in crispy wrap with cous cous. We ordered 2 pork belly and a lamb. To conclude our meal, we had the Sticky date pudding.The Truffle chips were served first, pipping hot with a huge serving of shredded cheese on top. The fragrance of the truffle oil was immense, totally tickled our nostrils.The pork belly was tender and literally melts in your mouth. The sweetness of the apple sauce nicely complemented the pork belly, lifting the palette from pleasure to joy. The portion was a little too much for me but a regular dude would have consumed it completely in glee. I didn't get to taste the lamb but I to say that it's not for the faint-hearted. The lamb is pungent (not in a bad way) so non-lamb lovers, beware. Now comes the sticky date pudding, the divine one that we all three swore we will be back when we need a pick-me-up. Rich and thick dark caramel sauce, coupled with a large scoop of vanilla ice cream and a really warm pudding, our tongue was dancing between the sensation of hot and cold and the sweetness from the sauce was balanced nicely with the ice cream. The pudding was moist and lovely.Dinner ended on a high note as we leave and were sent off with "thank you"s from the staff. So coming back for the sticky date pudding!

Great coffee + Great ambience = Great place to chill. Located at the corner of the Goethe Institute, this quiet corner offers simple but great coffees. Its extensive bar suggests it has a probably a bit more to offer thru its drinks offerings (have not tried it except for its strawberry basil soda).Food offering was the normal standard fare of cafe food, altho it did try to be innovative with respect to its "localised" presentation and taste. I wasn't impressed with its pasta of the day - an interesting interpretation of penne with cream and some sort of local soy-sauce base. Ermmmm ......

Finally back from all that traveling and am now getting back in touch with the food scene in Singers! Caught a little break at work and checked out the new kid on the block, The Lokal in the Duxton area. This new cafe on Neil Road is the offspring of Sarnies, another crazy packed cafe that I've yet to try (ZOMG call myself a food blogger).Well The Lokal checked off all the boxes on the hipster cafe checklist and they even went as far as to throw in a $40k Slayer machine. Oh that sexy beast took me on an intense ride with his latte ($5.50) and I must say it was all very smooth. And a little nutty too. The beans are from Sarnies and they have their barista consultant, affectionately known as the K Man, who is overseeing the coffee making for now. Many would go for the signature Veal Schnitzel Burger ($28) served with a tangy grilled pineapple and red slaw but we skipped that because chunky chips weren't available that day! Instead, i opted for the Roast Beef on Rye ($17). The sandwich was a combination of perfectly caramelized onion and thinly sliced sautéed beef. The flavors were a little sweet and could be sharpened with a stronger mustard than the current grain mustard crème fraiche. It was a good roast beef sandwich nonetheless.The Roast Chicken Panini ($15) was good too. The filling included huge juicy slices of fresh tomato (not the cheapo Malaysian sort), copious amount of avocado mash, crispy pancetta and salty roast chicken meat. The bread was our favorite among the lot of sandwiches we had, partly because it's a little more pillowy and chewy. A healthier option is the Smashed Avocado with Ricotta Sourdough ($18). The ricotta is made in house, along with their yogurt as well. It was simply topped with some pomelo and almonds, drizzled with olive oil. I liked the separate components of the dish but it came together rather plainly. A touch of honey could make this a better dish in my opinion but that's just my preference. I was looking forward to the Banana bread with Hokey Pokey ice cream ($12) but was sorely disappointed when I bit into the soggy bread cloyingly soaked by the citrusy syrup. We wondered where the ice cream went to as well (i swear i didn't take forever to grab a shot). Instead we had a sour cream sorta mixture on our dish. I couldn't bear more than a full bite of this one but K had no issue finishing it for us.Overall, The Lokal is a decent place for a hearty sandwich and it's probably going to be really packed on the weekends. A little bird told me that the Sarnies people are gonna be opening another cafe soon so do watch out for them!

Let it be known that the lobster roll is a SLIPPER lobster roll. Big difference and to be fair, it does say so in the menu description but still, the dish is called a lobster roll. Hrrm. It was greatly disappointing. Overall it's too big and there's too little slipper lobster. It's about 80% purple slaw and 20% slipper lobster. Just imagine getting slipper lobster 1 in every 5 bites. The slipper lobster was kind of tasteless and the roll was too huge and just a glorified hotdog bun. The handcut fries were excellent, though one wouldn't come back just for the fries, would one.

Nice location within around 6 mins walk from Outram Park MRT. The food and coffee here is okay. I like the atmosphere of the coffee shop with colorful decorations. It's a nice place to meet friends, it's quiet, the closing time is quite early though (I went there on Monday..).
Excellent coffee. Food is also solid. Even in a big group, everyone can find something to order. No complaints from anyone either. Except on the pricey side. Lines on the weekend, weekdays are fine

Chanced upon this cafe along Neil Road. Managed to get a table quite fast even though there was queue. The pork burger, muesli and eggs were surprisingly good but the place was too pricey for us. One visit was enough.

So many of these hipster cafe places springing up in Singapore these days; I can't keep track. Pardon me if I sound really jaded but... it's all starting to look the same? The slightly-deconstructed interiors, the limited brunch menu, the old-school plates and cups... same old, same old. With more than a hundred of such cafes dotting our little island (all springing like wildflowers in the past 3 years or so), it's starting to get a bit dated, and standing out is becoming somewhat challenging for all these cafes. Unfortunately, The Lokal fits into the typical mold of all the new wave of hipster cafes. I'd like to be more excited, but after visiting this place for today's Yelp brunch... I just didn't find anything that would make it stand out. Not to say that it's bad, it's OKAY, a DECENT but not fantastic place to have a meal.I ordered the roast chicken panini with a smoked salmon side. The smoked salmon was alright, though a bit cold (one of my dining companions thought that it was okay though). The sandwich came stuffed with the chicken, strips of crispy bacon, tomatoes and avocadoes. The vegetables tasted alright (tomatoes were better than other places... say, Subway), the chicken was sufficiently moist, the bacon was crispy but had no taste. We went in a group of 14 and sampled a good proportion of the (smallish) menu - the overall verdict was that it was ok, but nothing to shout about.I had a mocha. It was ok, not bad, but again- not amazing.The best part was probably the sticky date pudding, which was yummy and quickly gobbled up by one of the kids!Prices are reasonable and portions are decently-sized. My meal came up to slightly below $20 for a sandwich and a coffee, and I felt satiated at the end (although I wasn't satisfied). Verdict? It's alright if you happen to be in the area, but not worth traveling for.

Very cozy cafe at Chinatown/Tanjong pagar neighborhood. The flat white I ordered is above average. Toasted banana bread is great. The lemon yogurt pouring on top gives it a refreshing kick. Roast chicken sandwich with avocado and pancetta is very generous in portion. It would be better if the ciabatta can be toasted to be more crispy. But in general it is a good sandwich.

Singapore has no shortage of brunch places. Some have the typical eggs benny and french toast on their menu while others serve fancy coffee prepared using science lab equipment. The Lokal gives us a nice balance adding subtle touches to the usual favourites along with daily specials (i.e. Sunday Roast) that keeps regulars coming back while brewing a good cup of no-flash coffee. Only draw back is that because it's so popular, you occasionally have to share tiny tables. Although slightly on the pricier end, would definitely recommend this place for those brunch die-hards.

Terrible customer service. Came in thinking we wanted to try the food, took 10 minutes before anyone greeted us or said anything to us AFTER we got their attention ourselves. We were put on a waiting list and waited in the restaurants for 30min before we finally gave up. The staff are rude and unattentive. There were empty tables in the back, and staff would leave them empty for 15min before they sat anyone down. Skip the wait and the disappointment.
Got recoomended from a friend. Food and coffee are both good. The menu is quite unique

A 4.5 review (cannot seem to add the extra 1/2!). Excellent service- friendly and prompt. Real cold drip coffee! Ciabatta Chicken was really yum and the Smashed Avo, Ricotta on Sourdough I am told was fabulous. Great vibe for Friday lunch.

Real Aussie brunch joint.  Very fresh produce and crowded on the weekend.  Not exactly kids friendly as the place is crammed.  Food and coffee were divine and their peanut butter banana smoothie is to die for!  Services are good and price is reasonable but go early before the crowds get there.

We went here for breakfast. This place is definitely over rated. Their menu is really lacking. They had some really amazing smoked salmon, but their avocados did not seem fresh what so ever. Their scrambled eggs were also very mediocre. They also didn't have hotdogs, what kind of place doesn't have hotdogs

Hawaiian style poke - rare to find in Singapore and delicious to eat. However, the price is really high and I probably wouldn't be back to eat without the entertainer 1 for 1 offer. Alakai is located along Neil road at the end of the Everton estate. A small humble and cozy eatery with enough seats to fill 20 people or so. The tuna and salmon are kept in the typical ice cream freezer like other poke shops. They don't really need to cook any hot food because most of the items are premade. Thai chili salmon - nice spicy flavor and came with mangoes. Rice was topped with Japanese fish flakes which are very tasty. Also comes with a small potato salad and leafy salad Soy sauce tuna - classic tuna with small potato and a leafy salad. Rice is also topped with Japanese fish flakes. Rice is delicious and fish and salad is fresh. The only drawback is that each dish costs $18.90 so it is difficult to justify going back for a meal. Much more affordable if you use the entertainer 1 for 1 coupon!

Excellent authentic Greek!  Yes for Singapore!  A great casual environment, with friendly efficient service and the best garlic dip!  I also enjoyed the Kofte and excellent wine (at a reasonable price) which sometimes can be a hard find in Singapore.The kofte was excellent and the serving sizes ample. A great choice for dinner or lunch.

This place is only open until 11 PM and the kitchen closes at 9 PM. Yelp has a completely wrong. The baklava and Greek coffee was excellent I was unable to get any food because the kitchen was closed when I arrived

Typically I'm not a fan of Greek food, and also haven't had that many  opportunities to eat it either. So you can already know how I feel when the wifey dragged me to go eat at  Bakalaki Greek restaurants here in Singapore. Overall, I'm glad she did, the food was surprisingly fresh. My wife ordered the beef kebab and I ordered the chicken kebab. We ended up sharing the food.  The service and ambiance were both great and I ended up having a positive mood for the rest of the night. Bakalaki has made me a believer of Greek food.

they have easily displaced blu kouzina as my new favourite greek restaurant in sg!the spaciousness, airiness and welcoming thematic decor takes them a notch above the competition even before you get a chance to differentiate their plates.and as soon as you take that first lick of taramosalata off the olive oil glistened pita you will want more, asap.a greek salad like none i have had in greece, really fresh, generous and a good balance of texture, colour and acidity. just a little heavy on the salt, in my opinion and a common thread when it comes to the meat dishes.the pan seared greek cheese smoothly rounded off my selection of appetizers.so the eye is bigger than the stomach? the staff will beckon you not to over order.portions err on the excessive side, so under order if you must.i wanted both the meat platter and the seafood platter but was knowledgeably adviced against it by our more than helpful server.he gently steered us away from the meat platter and we ended up ordering the seafood platter with a lamb chop main to supplement my carnivorous desire.yes, grilling is definitely one of their strengths and the lamb chops stood no chance.devoured within seconds of arrival, medium rare and tender as one would expect.but the seafood platter is the highlight and i am glad i listened to my server.it's just less of the same and a better variety with more varied cooking methods.the whole sea bream is easily de-boned and demolished from head to tail.crispy calamari pieces were quickly snapped up like savoury popcorn.while the more mature octopus satiated the more adult palates.their version is lightly charred for a fuller flavour yet with a baby butt tender bite.the two big butterflied prawns was easy fodder even for non skilled peelers.was left craving to try some other meat and the beef skewer souvlaki was quickly nominated to fill just that void.the longish wait however detracted somewhat from the enjoyment when it did finally arrive.best order all at once.if you are lucky enough, a complimentary dessert of greek honey and cinnamon doughnut balls with chocolate dipping sauce will comatose you.efkaristo bakalaki!

I was going to give up on Greek cuisine until I found this place. All of the Greek places I tried before this place seemed to me that they were serving middle eastern food poorly prepared. This place is different!We went with the mixed meat platter for two and everything they had was good. I specially enjoyed the spiciness of the beef sausage and also enjoyed the lamb chop the most. The meatball is really good as well. The chicken yorio and the kebab are ok but nothing special. The portion is good for two people and you should order one starter if you aren't planning to eat dessert. We opted to eat dessert and ordered baklava and they gave us Greek yogurt on the House. The baklava was just ok nothing special. I would skip dessert next time but the meat there was really good.Highly recommend you reserve a table given it was fully reserved when we arrived and sat on the bar side

My Big Fat Greek Dinner It's been a while since we went to our favourite Greek restaurant (we shall just call it the old place) and I was shocked when I discovered that the entire management team had changed. After some quick research by the wife, we discovered that they've ventured out to open Bakalaki Greek Taverna at Seng Poh Road and we knew that we had to head down to give it a try. First impressions. It felt like being home again. The warm greeting from George and Christos is always something to look forward to and we loved how Bakalaki felt a lot like the original place at Upper Bukit Timah (with a lot more space). Saganaki Kefalotyri ($16.90)This simple looking dish has always been one of my favourite. This beautifully pan fried Kefalotyri is not overly salty and melting with goodness. Topped with a squeeze of lemon and it brings out the richness and flavours of the cheese wonderfully. Perffffferrcccctttttt! Best eaten hot! Horiatiki ($20.90)Definitely one of the best Traditional Greek salad around. The wife who doesn't normally enjoy raw salads really love the Greek salad here. The Cherry tomatoes used are amazingly sweet, mixed with the freshness of the cucumber, pungent-ness of the onions, the saltiness of the olives, creaminess of the feta and the brightness of lemon juice made this salad an absolute delight to have! Pita Bread ($2.90)The pitas here don't look like much but they are so so good. Light, almost fluffy, they go absolutely perfect with the dips (5 different dips) that are available. That hint of salt added a nice dimension to the pita while the oregano gave it a nice, earthiness to the pita.Dips ($14.90 - $15.90 for single portions or $16.90 for 2 half portions)We went with the 2 half portions for the variety and tried their Taramosalata (Cod roe dip) and the classic Tzatziki (cucumber and Greek yogurt). A little strange not seeing Hummus on the menu but at least it got us trying something different. The tzatziki was fantastic. Light, refreshing and a real palette cleanser as we moved from dish to dish. The Taranosalata on the other hand really packed it punch! It was wonderfully rich, salty yet had this brightness to it because of the lemon juice. And I might get murdered for this but it went perfectly well with not only the pita but with the potato and grilled octopus tentacles. Paidakia ($32.90 for 3 pieces) The lamp chops here are a must have and a favourite here. The lamp is wonderfully marinated, ensuring that, for the lesser fans of lamb, there isn't that overpowering smell of lamb. It's perfectly seasoned and the knife cuts through the meat like butter. It had the perfect amount of meat to fat ratio, ensuring the lamb chops remain juicy and succulent. For those who used to frequent the old place and know how good the lamb is, the ones here are as fantastic!Htapodi ($32.90)Another favourite and must have is the grilled octopus tentacles. A lot of love and care goes into cooking octopus tentacles (legs), ensuring that they come on tender and succulent. Grilling them alone isn't enough and it often takes and hour or so of braising. The octopus here doesn't get any more perfect. Juicy, succulent, tender, it is absolute bursting with the flavours of the mediterranean.  A must have, whether you're a regular or visiting for the first time. Thanks to Christos, we managed to try 2 new desserts on their menu.Rizogalo ($11.90)This creamy rice pudding was really quite a surprise. It looked really heavy but was actually very light, not overly sweet and perfect after a flavourful meal. Loukoumades ($14.90)Little puffs of sunshine. These little traditional Greek doughnuts and crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. Drizzled with honey and dipped in the chocolate at the side, it brought a little burst of happiness with every bite. Overall, I loved the hospitality of Bakalaki. It feels like you're being welcomed to a great big Greek family dinner every time you're there. The ambience is very nice and open and with a fairly open concept, it doesn't feel stuffy or stifling and makes for a very comfortable dining experience.

My visit here was based on a recommendation from a banking colleague.The decor is authentic modern Greek. I felt right at home straight away. The waiter was very compliant with our questions and changes to our order.The calamari was a little over cooked but still tasty. The egg plant was a great appetiser We had the meat platter for two which was very authentic. The lamb was great which I think is a hallmark of a Greek restaurant as well as the tazaki has lots of garlic which I likeOverall a good night out

I just had lunch at Bakalaki and I can't wait to be back for more. The vibe and deco of the restaurant momentarily transported me to a touristy (not in a bad way) seaside town in Greece. The food and service were both impeccable and left me in high spirits the rest of the day. I especially enjoyed the grilled octopus, which was juicy, soft and flavourful! The dips were also nicely paired with the warm toasted pita bread that was peppered with some herbs and coarse salt. The house wines added a nice touch to the meal as well.

This was my first 'proper' Greek food. In the past, my encounter with Greek food was in small restaurants that sells gyros. I came in without a reservation and was lucky enough to get a seat. I ordered bread and hummus for starter and had their Lamb for my main course. They were fantastic. The portion was quite big and I wished I came with someone else so I can try more food. Will come back for more!

tldr - good food but unacceptable service at this price point.My family visited on 7th July 2018 on the strong recommendation of a relative (we were planning to visit the other well-reviewed Greek restaurant in Singapore).It is true that this is one of the two Greek restaurants in Singapore worth its salt (or olive oil). Signature Greek items were very well executed - the taramosalata was rich and creamy without being overpowering. Of the items we ordered, we thought that Bakalaki did a better job on some while Blu Kouzina (the other Greek restaurant) did a better job on others. Overall, high-quality food.The service, however, was abysmal. I would have written it off if the poor service occurred once, but it happened four times - it was difficult to get anyone's attention to (a) get water refilled, (b) order additional items, (c) ask for the dessert menu, (d) pay.In fact, there were a few occasions where some staff walked by us to the shelves near to where we were sitting to do their thing, and they seemed to take extra care to avoid eye contact with me. The unnecessary delays added up and by the time we received the dessert menu, we decided to skip dessert.One possibility is that we were seated near a large group and the waiters were busy with that group. However, the maitre d should have assigned waiters accordingly. At Bakalaki's price point, this level of service was not acceptable.
Great food, fantastic ambience, good service. Would certainly recommend and visit again.Everyone with a sweet tooth must have the Galaktoboureko. MUST HAVE.

This place is awesome. It's just awesome. Food is great (the lamb!), servers are knowledgeable and friendly, ambience is bright and fun and even the toilets are nice and clean. I mean, what's not to like. Go there now. It's awesome.

This is a great Greek place. It is almost always full so a reservation is recommended. Great food and usually decent service. I have been there a few times. I went there recently with my wife and we had a few appetizers for dinner. I recommend the feta with honey and sesame seeds. Our waiter recommended the calamari so we ordered that along side a few other appetizers. Unfortunately that was a bit bland and chewy. We asked for a sauce and the waiter said, "yes, it can be a bit chewy."  I don't get why he recommended it to us if he knew it wasn't good. It made the rest of the dining experience a bit hard to swallow.

Just. Plain. AWESOME food AND service!  We were in town for a short weekend and felt like Greek so we gave this a try.  The ambience and interior of the restaurant is so beautifully done. The food, oh my!  We had a few dips, the meat platter and wine.  All worth it and highly recommended!

The food is good but probably less so than my other favourite Greek in Singapore. Most items were ordered were good, from the starters to mains to desserts. That said, the service here can be greatly improved. We made reservations more than 2 weeks in advance for a special occasion for 10 people. Yet, when our party arrived (10 minutes earlier than reservation time), our table had been given away. We knew this because we were told that our table was prepared but they were accidentally given away to a group of tourists. We had to wait for tables to be vacated, cleaned, set. We were initially squeezed into 2 tables, that was then extended to 3 when some other diners left. The service recovery was poor. I would be reluctant to return, especially when treated impatiently when the fault lies with the restaurant.In addition, the acoustics at this place is bad so it is not recommended for intimate/romantic dinners.

Nice atmosphere. Decent food. Tasteful decor. Ridiculously priced. We ordered the tzatziki and taramasalata dip combo as an appetiser on the waiter's recommendation. $17 for the dips. The tiny pita bread to dip in it is an extra $3. The moussaka for the main course was tasty enough but missing the cinnamon and nutmeg flavour. $26For dessert we ordered the rice pudding. Ample portion served in a mason jar but a bit dry. $12. The best part was the Turkish coffees. Nicely presented. $10 for two coffees. The total bill for the above including service charge and taxes was $80. Too pricey for what you get. Not the best value.

If you are looking for authentic Greek food in Singapore then look no further. The food is drool worthy and the ambience is very easy going and contemporary. The staff went above and beyond. They will first serve you some bread which is made in house (I always trust restaurants that make their own bread)and then you must order the aubergine dip with the pita breads (yes, carbs are good for you). We over ordered our food and finished off every morsel of it. My mom and I are vegetarians and unlike a usual dinner outing, we could eat almost everything on the table (except for a meat platter ordered by the rest of our group and was raved about). Don't forget to eat the desserts (or at least the yogurt with honey!!!) - you won't regret it. The food is so fresh and make with excellent ingredients that you won't feel anything but light and ridiculously happy after eating it :)

This place hands down have one of the best seafood dishes and Greek dishes I ever had.  The ingredients in their seafoods they served smells great and tasted fresh. I stumble across this place from my friend recommendation while I was touring Singapore, and I was not disappointed at all.  If you are visiting Singapore, definitely give this place a visit.  You will definitely like it.

Very nice Greek bistro that's newly opened.  Food was absolutely delicious and authentic.  They have a good selection of Greek alcohol and it's very much recommended.The restaurant is probably best for group dinners / lunch so that you can have more variety of the dishes.Will definitely go back.
Excellent service and great food.  The veggies were fresh. The meat was tasty.  Dishes were well prepared.  The Souvlaki and the skewers are both worth trying.  Nice ambiance as well.

This may be Singapore but Greece has  arrived. Probably one of the best Greek meals I have ever had. The atmosphere is nice and the food was even better. Recommend a Greek salad to compliment what ever fits your tastes.

Used to be at Craig Rd, but it has moved to a 2-storey shophouse since 25Mar2015. Now there's a Sake Bar on 1st level & Dinning area on the 2nd level.....interesting.A more cost set-up now.They are close on Monday. So guess other alternative on Monday.I like their lunch special/promotions, value for money.I have not been there since it open in 17 Kampong Bahru Rd, but definitely visit there soon.Will update soon when I'm there.Cheers.

We really enjoyed lunch with a few friends here. The cuisine is modern Singaporean, and its inside a beautifully refurbished hotel. The Popiah is delicious. The skin to wrap the ingredients was light yet not too delicate and the taste reminded me of the wrapping of an old school Hong Kong sweet snack. You are presented with a range of condiments to go inside the wrap ... and the whole experience is exemplified with a step by step instruction card that is a cute and nice touch. We also had their bak kut teh. It was slightly different to the usual style, the soup was tasty but heavier than usual, but the rib was soft and succulent and just fell off the bone!Another dish worth mentioning is the chicken. It was succulent and juicy, and was stuffed with rice in a dark marinate with bits of veggies and Chinese mushroom. Super tasty!A Kailan with Kale side was interesting ... the two types of kales coming together, served cold in a delicious sauce. The cocktails were good - my Lady Luck came in a fancy cup of a lady's head. My friend had a Kopi Cat - it was delicious, basically a kopi with vodka. Yum. Highly recommend - I don't give 5s often!

We came here to celebrate the richness of Singaporean flavors. Chic dining room adjacent to the beautiful hotel lobby. On a Friday night, the wait was long, partially because the dining room is not well managed: There are only 10 tables, yet most 4-seat tables only have 2 pax; one long table had 3 pax. The beef rendang and seafood congee are succulent, the Konbu mee (a variation of Hokkien mee) is good. Service is smooth, under the direction of an effort Amazonian British receptionist. Prices are indeed exorbitant. It is interesting for a visit, but given the short menu and pricing level, Labyrinth at a Esplanade is a better choice for mod Sing!
Poor service, menu wasn't fully available, staff wanted us gone before we even had a drink, food average at best, over rated!!! Terrible experience, extremely over priced! Don't waste ur money

I ate at Po last Thursday as someone else was paying the bill. The food fell in two buckets, very good and very meh, which put me on the fence given that this is a fine dining restaurant AND I have enjoyed Willin's food at Wild Rocket back in the day.Our meal started of course with the signature dish, Popiah. The skin was really, really soft and just flexible enough that a clumsy person like me could roll my own popiah and not tear it. Ok I lied. I ripped my popiah right down the center, but i ate it anyway because I don't know, it cost $58?! The chilli and stewed pork filling, which I would argue make or break the dish, did the job but lacked any kick. I mean this could have been a knock your socks off starter, but it tasted more like a dish I'd use to introduce Western friend's to local cuisine.What should've been our knock-your-socks-off starter was the charcoal grilled Iberico satay. Oh em gee. Now THIS, this giant succulent skewer chock full of slightly fatty pork, marinated in spices and then grilled, was just perfect. One of the best satays I've eaten and here's looking at you, Violet Oon at National Gallery. Next we had the barramundi salad, which was basically a yusheng plated to look like a garden with flowers. Very fresh fish, good dash of citrus and oils and aromatic flowers. Light and refreshing on the palate before the next porky dish, which was Kurubota char siew. Oh this had so much promise as it looked like the strips at Char and mm that Cantonese restauarant near Keong Siak. Alas this plate had some of the natural juiciness one would expect from Kurubota,  but it didn't have enough fat to take things to the next level. I really was disappointed since the plate was set right in front of me. Fight over the satays we did, but not the char siew.For mains, the standout by a mile was the prawn mee. It had these large chargrilled prawns sitting on pork laced, Hokkien mee style noodles that were just wet enough to slop on your plate and gobble down. Really really really really good. I was also looking forward to the paper spring chicken since it had glutinous rice stuffed in it, but it turned out very dry - makes sense because turkeys cooked with stuffing also get dried out and I imagine a smaller bird would have had a better chance with wet aromatics in the cavity and the rice steamed separately. Veal cheek rendang was also another meh dish - not exactly flavorful or falling apart at the touch of a fork. Why liddat?! Lastly the sambal forrest mushrooms were...fried mushrooms with sambal. Interesting combo, liked the sambal (so why couldn't the popiah chilli have more kick?). After eating pretty much the whole menu, we got what was incorrectly described as "Goreng pisang with gula melaka gelato". Gula melaka gelato....step right up! I actually tahaned a whole 20 mins more of conversation just for the dessert, only the realize what the menu meant was "Goreng pisang, drizzled with gula melaka sauce AND gelato". Haiyaaaaa. Anyway it was still a cool dessert - the goreng pisang was covered in those Chinese rice krispie thingies and fried, drizzled lightly with gula melaka  and then plopped on ice cream. It was delicious, lots of different textures and looked unusual.So there you have it. If I were to eat at Po again I would go straight for the satay, prawn mee and barramundi yu sheng. Drink wise I only got to try the whiskey based cocktail that comes in a bottle - it was quite well mixed though there was an overwhelming taste of caramel instead of banana and bitters. Stronger than it tasted so I enjoyed the kick. All in all, the restaurant was buzzing, some of the dishes were great but you're definitely paying up for it.

First time in Singapore. Our friend made reservations and while waiting, we had glasses of wine in the hotel bar attached to the restaurant. Staff were very friendly and courteous. Drink menu had a variety from cocktails to wine to beer. Our dinner include shrimp popiah (signature dish), prawns and noodles, and pork satay. All we're cooked to perfection. Popiah was similar to making your own burrito, except much more delicious!!! All in all, we loved the rustic ambiance and very chic vibe. Food was marvelous! I would recommend this place.

Food was decent but terribly overpriced. I asked the waitress how much we should order for two people and she made it sound like the portions were small and upsold us on way more food than we needed. However the real travesty is that the cocktails were some of the worst cocktails I have ever tasted and this is coming from an owner of a cocktail bar who has drank his way around the world. Get your cocktails elsewhere and maybe just stick to the popiah here.

Some hits and misses for our dinner at Po. The salted-egg fried softshell crab was good, but the charsiu did not. The mains were good though. Its a place I would bring guests to enjoy a Singaporean-ish meal in comfort.

Good food, good service and nice ambience.   Can't ask for more.   To me the most addictive is their satay lamb sticks!!  salty and well spiced with cumin.   the only draw back is of course parking.   was there on a Friday 5:30pm and already had a hard time finding parking.   This is a buffet so it is really meant for big eaters and all ingredients are fresh.

Prague Microbrewery and Restaurant represents a marriage of cultures, styles, tastes and culminating in an eclectic mix of refreshing Czech - styled beers and food!The lovely beers here are brewed by their very own in-house Czech master brewer and adheres to the fine traditions of Czech beer brewing standards and purity laws. All hops, malt and yeast are imported from Czech Republic.Microbrewed beers are natural, have no chemical, preservatives or additives added. They are unpasteurized and unfiltered, retaining all natural goodness and wonderful flavours.Here are some of their beer offerings :    Prague Light        Czech Pilsner (Svetle Pivo) 5% alc/ vol    Prague Dark        Dark Czech Pilsner (Tmave Pivo) 5% alc/ vol    Dark & Light Pilsner Brew        (Rezane Pivo) 5% alc/ volHelmed by Czech Chef Eva, Prague Microbrewery and Restaurant  tantalising menu includes traditional Czech specialities such as Roasted Pork Knuckle, Homemade Sausage platter, Beef Goulash, Roasted Duck with Cabbage & Dumplings, and Chicken Paprikash.Roasted Pork Knuckle $24++The pork knuckle was huge for the price tag! It looked so golden brown with the promise a good crackling time with every mouthful. The fats are plentiful, giving the meat flavour, but the skin wasn't as crispy as I had hoped. Nevertheless, still a great staple in most brewhouses!2. Roasted Duck with Cabbage and Potato Dumpling $18++ *Highly Recommended*This was my favourite dish as the duck was so tender! A signature Czech dish with traditional ingredients, the cabbage was also mildly sour with a good mix of juiciness.3. Chicken Paprikash $16++At first, I had mistakened this for a curry chicken with rice! The chicken itself was a bit bland but together with the delicious creamy sous, it was rather delightful.4. Beef Goulash $16++This is a traditional Czech pub food. The beef chunks are slow-cooked for hours with Czech spices till the stew becomes aromatic. The beef here were sizable chunks but didn't have the melt in your mouth texture I had expected. The stew was very flavourful though!Overall : Prague Microbrewery and Restaurant is the first of it's kind in Singapore that is very authentic and sincere in both their drinks and food. It is very conveniently located just above Outram MRT station.

address: Chinatown point  133 New Bridge Rd #02-39 Singapore 059413 Singapore
comment: You need to try the signature soy chicken dishes. The soy chicken is tender and tasty. You have to try with either noodle or rice. I loved the soy sauce lor Mee as you can see from the photos! Very tasty dish, not dry but enough sauce to coat the noodles served with crispy roast pork ! The Haikee Brother meal deal is value for money as you get two serves of the soy chicken and rice, share a soup and two drinks. The century egg congee with bbq char siew was generous with the century egg. A huge bowl for sharing with others. A great place for a meal, reasonable in price.

a great addition to the bustling f&b scene along this colourful stretch of keong saik road.my greatest worry is that the parking situation will definitely deteriorate henceforth........ah, tapas........in a cosy setting coupled with good service.not so easy to secure a table here but try you must.my experience here transported me back, in spirit, to the beloved barcelona i so miss!they are probably more pricey than one would like but such quality well executed, if shared amongst a group of like minded foodie, priceless.....i wanted to order everything!but knew i would definitely be back and thus was restrained....yes, i will be back.olivia will have you at hello and nothing, that i did order, missed the spot.there's even a special menu item, a tribute to elBulli.......since one can no longer have a meal there, ever, i'm glad i got a taste of them spherical olives tribute!as you enter or leave, the neon sign on the wall seems to suggest that their food is better than sex?i beg to differ, it was pretty close, olivia probably hasn't had much?;)

address: Craig Place 20 Craig Road #01-02 Singapore 089692 Singapore
comment: Binomio is a great choice for a fun date night out, especially now that the restaurant takes reservations for the front tapas bar area.  We like to belly up to the tapas bar and order the Tapas Tasting Menu, 6 tapas for $69, which includes almost everything on the tapas menu.  Compared with many other tapas options in Singapore, Binomio offers superior cuisine and value!Among our favorite items are:1) Croquetas Binomio: if there's one thing I learned from my dad about restaurants, it's that you always order the dish with the restaurant's name in it...and this was definitely an item we have ordered again and again!  Crispy on the outside, creamy on the inside (stuffed with ham, chicken and egg), served on pretty plates with garlic mayo, can't go wrong!2) Albondigas: juicy beef and pork meatballs jazzed up with fried baby squids and excellent tomato gravy; we order these almost every time3) Gambas al Ajillo: I pretty much order these are every tapas bar we go to and I love nearly every version and this is no exception...I especially enjoy dipping the bread in the garlicky oil!  Yum!4) Churros: Binomio's version is more airy than most, but no less delicious with a perfectly crispy exterior and chocolate dipping saucePARTING THOUGHT: keep an eye out for the specials of the night on the chalkboard...we didn't notice it until our third trip!  They always have something interesting up there and it's usually available as an option for the tasting!

address: Craig Place 20 Craig Road #01-02 Singapore 089692 Singapore
comment: This one had been on my list to try out for a long time. A hugely popular Spanish place, reservations are a must. Plus also specify whether you want the regular dining area or the bar as the menus are different.We tried the croquettes (amazing) and the chorizo with cheese (great) to start off. Their squid ink paella is very popular so we didn't get any of the tapas this time (but will be back to try just those some other time). Squid ink paella was excellent. For dessert we had the basque burnt cheesecake, the only item which I felt was a bit of a let down, didn't find it that different from a normal cheesecake (although it was still tasty). Had hoped for a flavor of more Spanish cheese in it. Even though, its a superb place to try out Spanish cuisine in Singapore!

address: Craig Place 20 Craig Road #01-02 Singapore 089692 Singapore
comment: Consistently delicious and quality tapas. Prefer the bar over their restaurant. Looks like you need a reservation for the bar also now. Before it was just first come first served.Surprised I haven't written a review about Binomio yet. I could have sworn I did.Sounds like praises have been sung by the other reviews already. Just co-signing here.Really like the Larios 12 gin & tonic they make with juniper berries.
