Cha Siu Pau (BBQ Pork bun) tastes good. The skin is soft to chew and the meat is just nice.  Siu Mai looks awesome too. Come to this place at 11am and there are plenty seats available. Once it goes to lunch time, the place will be crowded.

This restaurant is a popular spot for locals looking for dim sum. Regular lunch hours are a bit quiet, offering a menu selection of meals, and good choice for a relaxing lunch. Come 2:45pm, lots people start coming for the 3pm to 6pm all-you-can-eat Yum Cha. This is a great deal, with a great selection of dim sum being wheeled past your table in trolleys. There's also a dim sum menu for making special requests, but the trolleys are quite comprehensive and come by very regularly. But don't order more than you can eat - you may get charged for unfinished plates, although small leftovers seems fine.The food is great, atmosphere energetic and noisy (just like yum cha should be!). Come close to 3pm to be sure of getting a good spot!

Surprisingly a Hong King style dim sum place.  We came here cause Tak Po is closed.  This place is served with trolley. They come to you very frequent and staffs are friendly.  The restaurant is on the second floor , you will see the signage from far but kinda tricky to find the entrance. If you don't like peanuts, may ask them to remove it immediately served together with cutleries.

This is a surprisingly large hole-in-the-wall type dim sum restaurant with excellent food.  The restaurant's somewhat hidden on the second floor of a hostel, with entrances through the hostel's lobby and through a souvenir shop.  You can order from the good-sized menu, but the staff also wheels around numerous freshly made dishes for you to choose from.  Everything my group of folk tried from the wide variety of dishes was all very good.  (Admittedly, there were things that weren't to my taste, but what I didn't like, one or more of my friends thoroughly enjoyed.)
Food is getting mediocre.... too complacent... floors dirty and toilets filthy.  Need to improve to enjoy the heyday of popularity.

One of my favourite place to have morning Dim Sum with my family, this place is one of the few places that still serves Dim Sum in the old traditional way in push carts. The food is good although a little inconsistent. You have a wide range of chances which is good for a place like this and the price is affordable. Atmosphere of the place is to me way too chaotic, people pushing carts around, try to find the waiter and just kids sometime moving about. This is definitely a place I will quickly have my meal and just leave. Service is average, people were helpful but they did not go beyond anything that they were doing.
If you are looking for Dim Sum after walking Smith St this is the spot.  Spacious and authentic decor explains why even the locals like it here.

Went for lunch and ordered five dimsum dishes.Food was mediocre, BBQ pork pastry was too thick with little pork. Crispy silver fish was cold when served, and tasted bland. Staff were ok but service was slow.Probably not gonna be back as there's nothing special here.

Not a fan of this establishment. Food tasted bland which couldn't compensate for its dirtiness and poor service. I can't believe there was a long queue for this place. I'll never come back here and nether should you. Go elsewhere for dim sum.

Why did I fall into this tourist trap? The place is a zoo during lunch. Lots of families with kids, noisy, expensive. I had some bok choy, steamed coconut buns, turnip cake and egg custard tarts. That cost me $22 which is ridiculous even for US standards. The food is not even that good. Save your money and have  a $6.00 lunch downstairs at Smith Street.

Recommended to eat here for lunch by local business man.  Went just after lunch crowd had gone and it was more peaceful and relaxing.  Surroundings look like an updated traditional restaurant so you feel your in an authentic place and it's very spacious.  Staff could do with some customer care courses but on the whole ok!! We ordered 5 dishes of Dim sum and found them to be hot and fresh and were delivered to us as they were cooked which is usual in Asia, they don't usually serve all together or do courses. Would definaltely go here again and of you have visitors great way to see Chinatown and stop for a traditional lunch.

My fav place for dim sum!  I am not sure how we found this place right n the heart of Chinatown, with almost no sign pointing to it.  But i am glad we did.the food is consistently good, the service goes through ups and downs depending on what time it is and where you sit in the restaurant...  the atmosphere is just right!

This place serve dimsum. I went to this place for a late brunch around 11.30am and were second in the line. I didnt bother going early because I know there be long queue for it. This place seems to be more of a tourisy place as there are many western patronizing this outlet. However, the food remain nice and the service up to standard.  This is one of the several places where dim sum is not ordered from the waiters but they are being pushed around in the carts and you order from the cart.One down point is that it is pretty expensive with each item, which usually come in 3 pieces, cost around $3-4. Therefore, I suggesting visiting this place in multiple of three to more cost effective.

You get a very comfortable dining experience with the no-frills dim sum spread against a very cozy ambiance, notably the marble tables and classic wooden seats i.e. typical Singaporean. I like their har gows and siew mais, which is consistently good. Their porridge is also worth mentioning, cooked to the right texture. As for dessert, make sure you try their banana pancake.

Great dim sum place, very good food. Go early to get a table, it will be packed during meal times. Was there visiting with family and friends and place was crowded during brunch time. Service was a little slow, perhaps due to the crowd and it was hard to get our dim sum replenished quickly enough. It is also nicely located in the heart of Chinatown which make post-brunch shopping convenient. Would return again.

Very good kitchen, dim sum, seafood, deserts. Little hidden in a hotel (take escalators to 2nd floor). Good value and quality. In the heart of Chinatown, usually drop in for dinner after strolling through the small streets there.

I really loved Pasta Brava.  The service used to be amazing and  the food unforgettable.  You'd be greeted with a smile, you never even had to look around for a waiter - they were so attentive and the owner was always there - checking the food on the pass and talking to his guests.  I think there must have been a change of management because my recent experience at Pasta Brava was dreadful.  We were greeted with a scowl at the door, no one showed us to the table, they just pointed then turned away.  And the service was unbelievably bad.  I quote just two snippets of conversation with the waiterMe:  What does your veal come with?Waiter: Vegetables Me: And?Waiter: vegetablesIt came with carrots, beans and potatoes (seriously?)Me:  May we have the wine list?Waiter:  You want red or white?Me:  You have two separate wine lists?Waiter: No. (Stands there)Me: Well could I have the wine list then, pleaseWaiter: (gets wine list slams it down in table)The food was mixed. I opted for the carbonara which was just creamy delicious goodness sprinkled with bacon. My dining companion has the veal which was a slimy over tenderized mess with overcooked vegetables The desserts were brilliant - wonderful ice cream, well made coffee. It's a pity that the service and food slide so much when the owner's not there. He spent 20 years building a brilliant restaurant and the minute he's not there, it just slides.

I love Pasta Brava. It's on my favourite restaurants in Singapore and have eaten and brought several friends over many times. But this experience was just a bit sad for me . Especially if you ask each person to spend atleast 90sgd because its valentines day ,I expect the food to be on top.  2 star rating because i loved the roasted squid in squid ink mashed potatoes but the dessert was just so sad.The puff was so dry (obviously made before hand because of the crowded expectation on valentines day, but comon you guys are better than that. ) then put some cupcake cream on top not even butter cream just sugar with purple colouring to make it look fancy . My gosh.I always look forward to dessert but that was just sad.

Authentic Italy dishes with quite a few selections of wines. The staff are all very friendly and knowledgeable. They always recommend us something new when they have new releases. Their pasta are all freshly made and the ambiance is superb! I love their risotto as well. Please go and try! This place is definitely a hidden Jem. Great Italian experience. Will come back again for more!
Linguine al Granchio ($38 all in) - 4 stars for taste, 2 stars for valueTasted good, but nothing spectacular, and the price was exorbitant for a regular lunch.

It was easy to make reservation via chope.sg. Service was good (with the waiters filling up our water glasses and refreshing the plates) but the food portions were way too small. We had the spinach ravioli which was ok but for $20+ for 10 pieces of ravioli, didn't feel like it was value for money. The Beef with a chocolate and wine sauce was interesting and cooked well. However, after 3 dishes, we were still let hungry and ordered another 2 mains (and received some remarks from the service staff about the number of dishes we ordered). I really didn't like the duck ragout pasta dish as the pasta was coarse. Overall, i left the place feeling underwhelmed.

What works about Pasta Brava: It has a nice location that offers easy access after work. They offer a nice variety of dishes. Admittedly, their tiramisu is heavenly. Service is discreet and they threw in a complimentary tiramisu for my partner's birthday. Their menu is very reminiscent of the traditional restaurants in Italy that I've been to.We had the prosciutto con melone as an appetizer followed by the ravioli con carne & the stracci ai gamberi e capesante. To be honest, I found the fare to be of average standard. The highlight of the dish was the succulent scallops. The pasta was fresh but not done al dente like I had anticipated (though to be fair, the rumors had me expecting Italian style pasta). The sauces were pretty heavy and overwhelmed the taste of the pasta for the most part - something I'm not used to. Still, thanks for the service with a smile even when my partner and I were the last to leave on a late weekday night :)

A great place for those anniversary celebrations. The interiors are dimly (but aesthetically) lit, so you don't feel like you've come to such a busy place. The owner is good to talk to, they'd be happy to suggest you dishes in a no-nonsense way. Don't expect to be pampered here, really. The food is amazing. We had ravioli and risotto, both amazing. The third dish (ordered on the owner's recommendation) was something the likes of which I'd never had. It was basically two massive sausages on lentil (dry version of the indian Dal). Very interesting. Indeed. LIn short, the place offers you a great evening, is centrally located, and is much bigger on the inside than what the facade suggests. Not to forget, it's not overly costly.
Been one of my favorites for 25 years. Outstanding food, excellent selection of wines, attentive and professional service and lovely ambience.

Here to celebrate our anniversary with my favourite cuisine. Read from other reviews that the service is poor so we braced ourselves. When we arrived, we were seated and the restaurant was only running on 20% capacity for lunch. During ordering, staff was helpful to give advice on the food items. I was pleasantly surprised with one of the service staff who over to fasten a back cushion for me. That's awfully sweet of him to go to that extra mile for me. Grilled Eggplant - tender slices of eggplant grilled till soft and then served with melted cheese and tomato sauce over them. Perfect starters!Calamari - I think this dish fell short somewhat. The batter was soft by the time we ate them and though the serving size was quite generous, I found the calamari rather bland. If not for the tomato dip that accompanies the rings, it would totally tank. I won't order this again. Ravioli Con Carne - this is our best pasta dish of the meal! Little pillows of soft beef dressed in a strong tasting cheese sauce, something like blue cheese but not. Just really yummy lah!Before our Squid Ink pasta arrived, we were both offered bibs that they nicely secured on for us. I supposed if the black sauce splatter on you, it'll be quite a nightmare to remove. So thoughtful!!Squid Ink Seafood Pasta - quite a big plate of pasta that is a whole plate of Nero (that's Italian for black) goodness. Seafood is fresh and generous in amount. The squid ink sauce is very flavourful and every mouth of al dente pasta a party in the mouth!Spinach Ravioli - very good ravioli with tomato sauce. Not that this is not nice, it IS but this dish does pale in comparison to the other 2 pasta dishes. You can opt to have a half half of the Ravioli pastas on the same plate. This is what we did so we got to taste more without being too full!!Tiramisu - a nice generous square of cake. You can really taste the rum in it (nice!) and with the mascarpone cheese cream, a wonderful slab of heaven to finish up the meal. I dunno why so many complained about the poor service because we have enjoyed very good service, not just from one service staff but all round really. Will definitely be back to savour the rest of the menu!

This was kind of an odd experience. It is not really Italian food. Like If you told me there is an Italian chef I would ask you to prove it. This is definitely a local take on Italian food. But unlike Pastamania, which is so intentionally terrible that just thinking about it risks sending me into a fit of rage, this was actually pretty good.The ribollita was just not following that recipe, it was much closer to a minestrone. The seafood stew was almost as good as the Cioppino at Cicheti, The eggplant starter was a highlight, although I am not sure if they use Italian mozzarella. The minced beef ravioli was good like everyone says. The chocolate lava cake was worth it.
Rude, pompous service and pretentious starters.The Ravioli Con Carne was really good though!

On the outside it looks like a ordinary restaurant but when you walk in, it feels a little like a movie scene of waiters welcoming you into a cosy setting of a restaurant. The aroma and decor instantly brings you into the mood of Italian cuisine. Just before I go into the food, I'd like to commend that the service here is fantastic, fabulous and fawesome!The pasta served is surreal and yet tastes as down-to-earth as it gets. If you don't get what I mean, it means you can't say its anything out of the ordinary yet it tastes fantastically good, legendary in fact.This is definitely one of the more accessible (in terms of price and location), welcoming and affordable best pastas you can find in Singapore. Remember to call to reserve on weekends.

Booked a table for 10 for my wife's birthday. Brought a cake for the celebration and upon arrival were told that there was a corkage fee of $60-70 for the cake (I can't remember the exact amount). Extremely annoyed that the person taking our reservation didn't inform us of this charge given the party size and considering its not very common in Singapore (or maybe I only eat at Chinese places). Left a bad taste in everyone's mouth. On to the food. Some people in my party really liked it. I thought it was meh, inferior to Ah Bong's Italian. Pasta was overdone probably to suit local tastes. My main beef is that they used really crappy, tasteless, farm-raised shrimp for their seafood dishes. For the love of God please stop this practice. I wouldn't mind if they raised their prices and used actual quality ingredients.

Best pasta restaurant in town. I had carpaccio for their appetizer and crayfish pasta for my main and Choco lava cake for dessert which are awesome. Their tiramisu is also v yummy! And reservation is required. Rem that!

The price is high side, but the food is excellent. One of the nicest Italian foodand definitely looking forward to try again the squid ink spaghetti with seafood which went well with Barolo. Service rendered was perfect and quick, staff were very attentive to our needs as well. It is located within walking distance from Tanjong Pagar Mrt so location wise was a good choice.Just a warning before you start ordering your meal, the pastas here are quite hearty and filling so maybe side orders would not be an added option. As silly as it sounds, i have never tried any risotto dish in Singapore before so i was keen to try it here. I ordered the Risotto Al Funghi Porcini, which is Arborio Rice cooked with Porcini Mushrooms, White Wine & Parmesan Cheese simply scrumptious. That changed my opinion of risottos as i thought it was a meal with bland rice and it was supposed to be dry.Overall i think i may visit this restaurant again for the variety of pastas that they offer.

It's a pretty homely restaurant, rather dimly lit but we had a nice cosy table reserved for us in the corner. The menu's made to look like an Italian newsletter, and after much poring over the extensive menu, my group started off with the prawns and portobello mushrooms for starters; both were quite good. The bread that they served up was also quite yummy, and went particularly well with the garlic butter sauce of the prawn dish.For mains I ordered the ravioli with minced beef and gorgonzola cheese - they warn you that it's a blue cheese before you order, which is probably good for those who aren't that familiar with the cheese names. the ravioli was quite good - definitely for cheese lovers though!We were a little stuffed by then so no dessert, but overall quite a charming place for a decent Italian pasta meal!

Pasta Brava serves up good ol' unpretentious Italian food that probably has its roots in the recipe books of grandmothers who spent a lifetime perfecting the art of pasta making. I have a bad habit of ordering the same thing off the menu over and again - but only because it was really good the last time. I usually start off with prosciutto accompanied by slices of rock melon - not exactly the most challenging culinary feat but they always manage to get really sweet melons that pair nicely with the sharp salty taste of the meat slices. For mains, I am hooked on their squid ink pasta. Probably not the best choice if you are on a first date and hoping to impress. The last thing you need is to look like a giant squid self-imploded in your mouth. If that isn't an issue with you, tuck right in. The sauce is never over-powering and the squid slices are never rubbery - a fine balance that few achieve. The interior of the restaurant is warm and cosy with its dark wood paneling. A perfect location for a date or a long languorous dinner with friends.
The 5 stars is purely for their desserts only. Their lava cake is the best in town!

Unpretentious and straightforward Italian. Come here for the huge range of.. well, pastas. Of all sorts. In all ways. There is also a substantial list of main courses. And Italian wine of course.The restaurant is pretty and homey and the service is pretty decent. Prices are also quite good for this sort of food so it's not wonder that lots of people think so too, judging by the long queues.

Nice atmosphere when you walk in and a friendly greeting. You really get the feeling that you're in Italy (wall decorations, music, menu lay-out etc.) I ordered pasta carbonara , which was delicious. My friends were also satisfied with their dishes (risotto, steak, pasta's). Finished with a chocolate lava cake, which was divine! Another nice aspect; the crayons. You can draw on the paper sheets while you wait for your food. Fun for kids, but also for adults!

This is a very decent italian restaurant with a very friendly Italian owner! We were quite fortunate to get a table with no reservations just by the window and it was perfect. Spinach ravioli and fettuccine carbonara were very tasteful, and lava cake was just amazing! Prices are very reasonable. Wine was very good and not too pricey as well. We had an amazing time there and the atmosphere was homey and relaxed. Will definitely go there again. Bravo!

I went here because I met Aaron, who is a cook here at a birthday party, and I honestly did not expect much: an Italian pasta place in Singapore. But I was pleasantly surprised: the interior feels European (have I been away too long?) with wooden beams and Ensor-like drawings. One thing I particularly appreciated is that the owner hovers around all the time (may be stressful on the staff, but it does ensure quality): one moment, he was actually cleaning the stairs, then talking to people at the next table. This is not just a pasta place, but a true Italian restaurant. Can't say much more: I had spaghetti alle vongole and panna cotta. Both as they should be: the pasta al dente, the vongole succulent, the panna not too soft, not too hard. A good experience. And Aaron came to say hello...

Lao You Xuan's Seafood Soup is definitely a treat. Imagine a piping hot bowl of savoury and tasty soup with a generous serving of sliced fish, fresh prawns, fish balls, topped with crispy fish skin rolls. It matters not whether you enjoy the soup with a bowl of steamed rice or your choice of noodles (kway tiao, thin bee hoon, thick bee hoon, mee pok, mee kia, mee sua), because this soup is made to indulge. It's comfort food at its best.

address: Blk 82 Tiong Poh Road #01-03 Singapore 160082 Singapore
comment: Skip the chili crab!!! Go straight for the pepper crab.  Trust me.  There is so much hype with chili crab but honestly, the pepper crab is soo much better.What to eat here:bamboo clamssingapore noodles. Don't even know what this is called but I asked for a noodle dish that is popular with locals.  super thin noodles with shrimp.  looked deceivingly bland but was packed full of flavor.pepper crab!Most of the staff does not speak english.  This is def a local place so just see what others are eating and get the same thing.  You can't go wrong.

address: Blk 82 Tiong Poh Road #01-03 Singapore 160082 Singapore
comment: One of my favorite seafood places in Singapore. We love the Tiong Bahru area and the outside here makes it very relaxed and casual. The food options are quite extensive. Good variety of seafood but also chicken, pork and tofu dishes.The mapu tofu is not great, does not have any senchuan pepper in it. I do keep coming back

address: Blk 82 Tiong Poh Road #01-03 Singapore 160082 Singapore
comment: simply good old-school homestyle cooking in the tiong bahru enclave. this place looks like the set of some period drama (I'm not sure period is necessarily appropriate - is a history of 48 years enough?), from the simpler days of kampung living. it's open-air seating, old-school cutlery, and the loud buzzy feel of community you don't much get nowadays - and the food's pretty good.there's something about this place that strikes me as being incredibly poignant, though I've never lived through the era this place seemingly 'reminds' me of - the area is incredibly old-school (which explains the new hipster occupants), and it's seldom you get to eat in such a large uncovered space anymore. not fancy-shmancy at all - the sort of place you could bring the grandparents and extended family - and well-suited to any raucousness.they do cze-char and seafood dishes - but we stuck to their fish steamboat, which came quickly and with a broth intense with hours of cooking. their free-form meat and fish balls also deserve a mention - free-formed rounds of pale paste that cook up to bouncy, fresh specimens.we also got a couple of cooked dishes (largely spurred on by seeing them delivered to the other tables) - a deep-fried spring chicken arrived with thin golden skin and tender meat; and our spare ribs had a great sauce dark with vinegar, though had too little meat and was both fatty and boney.it's not fanciful food, and also not the best cze char I've had - por kee just a couple minutes away might do a better job, but these two places remind me of exactly what it is our parents are missing when they see the country changing - and sometimes you realise just what it is we may be losing what with all our new hipster coffee joints and hyped food imports.worth a visit - it makes for a great family dinner.

I never thought much about this place which was known for its healthy rice bowls, as I felt it was overpriced Economy Rice (Cai Png 菜饭), until recently I saw a 3-course meal offered by Chop. At $25, the meal includes a starter, a choice of main and a dessert, which I felt was value for money. Only cash and NETS is accepted here.Ebisu (ala carte $18)Pan-seared Hokkaido Scallops, Mussels, Miso Butter Cream and ToastIt was served pipping hot. The seafood was covered in a sea of rich creamy flavourful gravy, which I wished for more.From the 4 choices of main, I selected Tsukiji (ala carte $16)Tuna tataki, asparagus & edamame, onsen egg, pickled cucumbers, cherry tomatoes, furikakeI selected Orzo as my choice of base. There were other choices such as Ninja Rice and Garden Greens. The orzo ( a form of short-cut pasta, shaped like a large grain of rice) was topped with a savoury gravy and quite tasty on its own. The onsen egg added a rich creamy layer to the orzo. The asparagus was soft and crunchy. The pickled cucumbers was tangy and crunchy, while the tuna was smooth and fresh.Fancy French (ala carte $16)Fig jam french toast drizzled in ume-boshi infused honey, fresh grapes, plums, homemade hazelnut butter.This dish had a 20 minute wait. It looked quite pretty. The fruits was fresh and juicy, the toast sliced easily although I wished that it could be crispier.Accompanied with Coconut Lemon Mint ($8)Fresh coconut juice, lemond wedges, mint leavesIt was basically fresh coconut juice, filling with thick coconut flesh. Refreshing, although a bit cheated by the fanciful name.Overall the food was delicious. Best come early as the place get crowded easily, and could get quite noisy after that.

I really wanted to like this place as I've been on the hunt for healthy stuff but just a little disappointed with what I had. I had 'Noka' with Ninja rice. I loved the rice ($2 top up) but came in tiny portion! The beef cheek was really goooooood and worth it. However, I did not like the wetness of the whole dish, they could've strained the beef cheek juice before it's served. I don't think I'll be back. I still prefer Grains Trader located in 100am Mall which is still within the area.They have cold press juice too (@$7) but the choices depend on what fruits they have during the day itself.

Popped by here on a Saturday for a quick and healthy lunch; glad to report that it did not disappoint.I got the salmon bowl on rice, and my companion got the chashu bowl. The salmon bowl came with raisins and lots of veggies. I felt the salmon didn't have a heavy dressing, and that was what I was after. If you're looking for a Teppei-style bowl, this may not be for you.The real winner was the pork bowl. Pork on rice, with a heavy porcine flavor, an onsen egg drenching the goods, and pumpkin and cherry tomatoes for relief, wow! I would return to have this, over and over.The place gets busy so we waited a bit, but there was free wifi. Water is self-serve.

Kamo duck bowl ($21.40 + $2 for brown and Japanese rice on Honestbee) - 2 starsThe pan seared duck was way too tough! I ordered the wrong thing clearly. The rest of the bowl was alright but not worth what I paid clearly.

Healthy superfoods bowls served naked, for the naked super you. Tuck into hearty, value-for-money meals at the newest concept to hit the hip dining enclave of Duxton Road - Ninja Bowl. You lucky CBD folks now get carb-free/low-carb Japanese-inspired superfood meals, as well as delicious all day brunch items. Each of the 8 bowl starts out carb-free but you have the options of healthy fillers. I'd go for the super high protein White Quinoa ($3); Ninja Rice (blend of blend of vinegared Japanese pearl rice and brown rice with furikake); Garden greens for $2. Fans of Japanese chashu will love the Buta ($14). I thought their slices of homemade cured aburi pork belly were better than many ramen places in Singapore. That velvety blend of meat and fats with a smoky char, sweet balsamic tomatoes, sour-sweet ume-pickled apples, roasted pumpkin seasoned with seaweed flakes and sesame seeds, were gelled nicely with  a runny onsen egg. So much love for this one!The Kabuki ($14) will make you love chicken again for the tender pieces of deboned chicken thigh are marinated in miso, soy sauce, garlic and honey. Sous-vide and then seared, expect juicy morsels accompanied by baby corn, homemade pickled beets, an onsen egg, snow peas, and a final sprinkling of fried shallots. The salmon poke ($16) pales in comparison after all that bursts of flavors in the other bowls. I couldn't quite taste the soy and ponzu sauce that the salmon chunks are supposedly marinated in. Each bowl comes with greens and a sprinkling of quinoa already, but I'd certainly recommend a carb base to help fill you up. Fish lovers could also tuck into bowls with pan-seared tuna tataki, or a saucey slice of unagi.While the bowls may be what give Ninja Bowl its name, what may bowl diners over is their All Day Brunch offerings. You will see the same ingredients being used, but now paired with creamy scrambled eggs and fragrant sourdough slices. I had the best rendition of braised beef cheek with eggs for only $17! Certainly I would never have this dish again at Common Man. You could also have the 24h braised beef in a bowl too. More Japanese inspired plates with unagi on toast ($19), and that umami miso cream Hokkaido scallops and mussels ($18). Make sure you soak up all that goodness with the bread. The latter works perfectly as a dinner starter. Love!Definitely have the Fancy French ($16), a homemade fig jam filled buttery brioche. Oh that light woody cinnamon scent, salty-sour umeboshi (pickled plum) infused honey, and the homemade hazelnut butter, created a great mix of flavors that will send anyone to breakfast heaven. It's so good that I finished half of it despite having this at the end of our meal! This pretty plate has a wait time of 20mins so order immediately. Sides, cakes, and caffeine (Smitten coffee) are available at Ninja Bowl too if you need something small (or more). There is also a weekday Tea Time Set ($10.90) available from 3pm onwards. Coffee, tea or me?Love love love Ninja Bowl! Definitely a go to for all my dietary needs. :))

Heard about this place with healthy rice bowls and wanted to try it out. Sadly, both the food and the experience was lacking.We had the Noka (braised beef cheek), Buta (char shu) and the Yasai (salmon poke). Each bowl was about $16-18 (the price indicated on the menu does not include the base, you'll have to pay more for rice, salad, etc).First, the experience. The place doesn't take credit card, which is quite unacceptable given its location and the price of its offerings. Second, I wanted to change my order about 30 seconds after I paid (Wanted rice instead of orzo), and the cashier informed me that they could not do refunds. Seriously?Never mind, perhaps the food will live up to its expectations.The food came pretty quickly. However, the braised beef cheek had a weird aftertaste. The char shu was nothing special. The poke was ok, but the amount of poke given was tiny compared to other places with poke bowls around the Tanjong Pagar/Telok Ayer area (which also happen to charge less).The food would have been acceptable, but it was way too expensive for what it was. Coupled with bad customer experience, this place is just not worth the visit - especially with so many other good food options around the area (whether you want healthy food, salads, poke bowls, or rice bowls). Food is worth 2.5 stars, but the price and service brings it down to 1 star for me.Pros:- Free water is available- There's air-con in the placeCons:- Too expensive for the portion- Taste is so-so- Bad service experience- Much better alternatives around the area

This place was just delicious! Worth the 30 minute wait. We went on a Wednesday night at peak dinner time at 7pm. Not too bad of a queue if you ask me. They offer cold barley tea while you wait outside.The place is tiny! Only about 14 counter seats.Service was good. Very friendly. They only take Cash or Nets.There are only two things on the menu: US Prime Beef for $13 or Wagyu for $28. Both are good but if you can afford the Wagyu, go for it! Nice and tender beef!!! They cook it right in front of you and it is so fast. Because we're in Asia, they cook the beef medium. Make sure to ask for medium rare! They give an egg on the side for you to scramble and pour over the beef don. Definitely hit the spot with deliciousness.Comes with some side dishes: tofu, pickled veggies and beets.They have house made drinks like Sakura Cola and Wasabi Ginger Ale.Minus one star only for the numerous annoying little flies flying around. They need to seal the windows better or get better ventilation or something!Otherwise, would definitely return whenever I crave some delicious Japanese beef don and be prepared to wait in queue and swat those flies!

Nice selection of local microbrewery beer, I enjoyed the flight tasting and had a taste of the green beer! My cousin and his wife wanted to show me where they normally spend their weekends, LOL. We waited for the chef to show up due to traffic but the food was great! The laksa pizza is a must try and the lightly steamed oysters were amazing. The owner is very friendly and nice! Great place!
Good beer price and nice place to chill the night away!! We ordered two monster green beers! It looks like the stuff the HULK will drink on Friday night

Solid place to try local craft brews from people who have a passion for local craft beers.  They had 10 taps of which only was a guest tap from HK.  A sampler is a great way to go, and while it's $28, the pours are generous, which allows one to really enjoy each beer.  It's great to see a growing list of breweries with quality products.  Food is also quite good with a mainly Japanese menu although you can get things with a local flavor like a laksa pizza.  It's a nice addition to Duxton and also a great showcase of what's going on with the local beer scene.

TIPS:-Reserve a table prior to coming to the restaurant-Get your camera ready because every corner is Instagram-worthy :)CONS:-FOOD IS EXPENSIVE. I cannot recall exactly how much I spent but I remember my coffee being around $10 & my eggs Benedict being $20-30-Service was pretty bad...not going to lie. PROS:-Each thing on the menu was referenced to the show which I thought was super cute!-Eggs benedict was yummy & it came out on a cutting board and all the other side dishes for that entree were perfectly placed so of course I had to take a picture of it!

My husband and I watched "FRIENDS" every night when we lived in Singapore so I said, why don't I check out the actual cafe right here? Well. It was bound to happen. I went to a tourist trap. It isn't the exact replica per se of the famous TV show, but they've got the weathered couch and Monica's kitchen (off to the side of the main entrance) spot on. Of course, you'll notice some familiar decor (Joey's white dog art, Ross' Unagi moment captured on photo) around too. They play FRIENDS re-runs constantly on the big screen and everytime the intro song plays, the staff will stop to clap to the beat. Right off the bat, you'll notice that the menu is full of catchphrases and puns from the long running TV show, like Janice's Oh My God baby ribs, Chandler's Thanksgiving Dinner, etc. It's cute and funny, but not worth the multiple dollar signs. I was really glad that I had lunch beforehand, so I only paid S$8 for a latte. I had to do it, so I could also have the opportunity to sit on the couch and take my picture. Because, if you didn't take a photo, were you even there?
Quite the disappointment. I am a big fan of the series and on travel to Singapore.  They don't carry much souvenirs & what they do have is too expensive and super cheaply looking.

This place was OK. My steak was quite tasty but overly expensive for the quality and the size of the portion. It was a neat experience if you are interested in the FRIENDS series because they have a recreation of the apartment Monica and Rachel lived in as well as Ross's. The menu is themed to the series as well.

Five stars for recreating a 90s favourite! We enjoyed looking through the set design, taking photos on the famous orange couch, and watching episodes of friends on the projector while we sipped our coffees. Most of the complaints here seem to be about the food. We didn't try it, so no comment there.If you're a fan, this place is definitely worth checking out. Don't order a meal, however. You're in Singapore! You shouldn't be eating here anyways, when there's so much the city has to offer.

I was really looking forward to an amazing experience but it really fell short. The food is terrible and the service is even worse. But hey, where else can you go to grab a nibble or a drink and sit in a place that looks like the scene at FRIENDS and watch FRIENDS episodes? The menu is entertaining and witty, but they really need to improve their service and food. My Thanksgiving sandwich didn't even have a moist maker! Huge disappointment. The cheesecake wasn't even good enough to eat off of the floor! They really could do better.

F. R. I. E. N. D. S. Yeah!!! Who does t want to come and have coffee in Central Perk?! The inside is incredible! The real thing! Surrounded by Friends memorabilia, the show playing in a constant loop, the couch! It was a fun environment! The menu is very appealing and the coffee is fantastic! But the food tried too hard. My macaroni and cheese featured truffle oil. Yum! Except that it was like the whole bottle. The odor was so pungent I had to put my leftovers (almost 1/2 of it) on the other side of the table. The fries were almost amazing! Piping hot! But overly oiled (I'm seeing a pattern here) and no real flavor. Shawn and Ry shared the meatball sub. Made with barbecue sauce instead or marinara (not sure Joey would approve if that) the resounding feedback was: not that great. Very high prices in my opinion. Huge potential. Not quite there. We will probably go back, but as a tourist destination, not to actually eat.

If you're a fan of FRIENDS this place might be for you but I had high expectations for this cafe. The decorations really looked like it was from FRIENDS (obviously) but the food was...good. The food tasted good, it had flavour and the cheese on the pizza was very melt-y (I don't know if that's a word or not) but... it DiDnT WoW mE. They also show episodes from the show. There are some things that the cafe can improve on. The cafe should play music from the 90s than music now so there can be more of a retro vibe. They should also change the price of their foods and drinks. Some of the drinks are overpriced for what they actually are. The drink that I got (the Monica Getty...I think) was probably 14 DoLLaRs, which is kinda a lot for a medium/regular sized drink...

The place was empty because the food is terrible. If they would just improve the food, the place would be full. I don't understand why they are wasting the opportunity. The pizza had too much unmelted cheese. The macaroni and cheese had no taste.

The idea is cool... but the food and drinks are expensive. We order a mint tea, ($6) a cappuccino ($8) and a dessert ($16). Our dessert was suppose to have a helium balloon attached to it - but they struggled to get the balloon big enough. They called us to the counter to watch... but it didn't quite work, many times. After awhile I asked if we could sit and finish our tea / coffee because they were getting cold. The ice cream melted while they tried to inflate the balloon, so they brought us another scoop. In the end, I told them to stop trying because it had been about 15 minutes and we wanted to get to the airport. They still charged us full price which I was surprised about.

Not a regular place where you can have a decent conversation because the screening of "Friends" is a bit too loud . The service is nothing to shout about. Prices are rather pricey ...  it's a one time visit for me.

If you are a FRIENDS fan coming here may bring you tears of joy just by walking in. The set-up is pretty amazing - spot-on, lots of cool items from the actual show, you can even watch the show while you eat. Worst tasting food I have ever purchased in my life, hands down. The mac & cheese tasted like throw up. Not only is the food terrible but so is the service, and prices are expensive. But, you do not pay to come in to the famous Central Perk Cafe, so it sort of balances out. 2 stars instead of 1 for the awesome & internationally famous aesthetic. But if you are not a fan of the show - never come here.

For the friends lovers of Singapore, you have to go to this cafe!! The couches are always reserved, so call ahead if you want one of them. The food selection, in my opinion, isn't that great and it's quite pricey. The coffees are decent. They screen episodes of friends on a projector so it's hard to not enjoy your time here!

Food: The hummus was smooth and creamy and definitely the best I've had in Singapore so far. Salad and vine leaves were also delicious and tasted very fresh. Only downside was the falafel was over-fried.Service: Waitress was prompt to come take my order after I sat down on one of the bar seats outside. Wait for food also wasn't too bad. Even though I was the only one sitting outside, I didn't feel neglected at all. Unlike most places in Singapore, note that the menu prices already include GST and service charge is discretionary. (I overheard a customer complain that the meal was expensive and the waitress had to explain why.)
This is probably the best Mediterranean restaurant I've been to in Singapore. Great Hummus, chicken kebab and the fish is to die for.

Quality hummus that is good portion for two- three people. The Moutabal Baba Ghanouj (cold mezza hummus) was good but it was hard to taste the grilled eggplant and tasted like the classic hummus with a hint of lemon. They also had Interesting mediterranean dessert selections displayed that you can order to dine or take away. Note: self-service for water so no service charge was credited!

Pretty bad to be honest. The shwarma wrap was small (only slightly bigger than a normal iPhone), skimpy on the ingredients and lacking in flavour. The fries were cold. The savoury drink was so salty my wife couldn't take more than a sip (we've had this drink in many places before). Worse yet, it was expensive. Don't bother.

Its a nice middle eastern place but the prices are expensive. For example, the set meal that was 12.90 is now 19.90. Other prices have followed the same ratio.Food however is good. had the kibbeh, arayes and lamb kebab. All are tastefully done. But its the price that is going to make me think twice before I go there again.

Great Mediterranean food downtown.  Been looking for a place like this since I got here and thank goodness it's near work.  Not cheap though but found the tabouleh excellent.  I could eat that stuff all day.  Hummus was excellent as well.  Spicy lamb skewers were good and filling though probably big portion for lunch.  Recommend the wraps if it's a lunch meal.

Uhhhhhh what happened to this place? They revamped their interior, went further north on the prices, and smaller in portion sizes! What's that all about? What was working for them before was the good food at a great price... Bahhh, so disappointed.

When we want good cheap Middle Eastern food, we come here.  The prices you see listed include GST, and there is no service charge, so 2 pax can come out full here for $60. Whereas other Middle Eastern places cost 20% more. Also, water is served for free.Everything tastes really good. We like the hummos, it is very smooth. Hummos with garlic is excellent. The sampler mezza platter is a good way to try a lot of things.  They also have pita pizzas, wraps, and more fancy entrees. We usually stick to the appetizers because they have such variety.

this place is a great place for the money.  the mezze platter is huge with some great selections.  the hummus was our favorite.  i tried the swarma and was very happy about it.  we also did the chicken which was cooked perfectly.  everything was fresh and the service was good.  i will for sure be back.
Just had lunch here. Nice, clean place. The hummus and shawarma were both very good. I will definitely be back.

Had a light lunch at Urban Bites today. Fairly standard sterile lunch bar décor, service wasn't great and wasn't bad, food was pretty decent. Appreciate that the breads are baked in a stone oven and the baba ghanoush had the right amount of smokiness. I had a chicken wrap which wasn't over-impressive in either size or contents but still filled the gap. The grilled chicken was perfectly cooked although, not a whole lot off it. There were some tomatoes, pickles and a garlic sauce that lingered on my breath for hours afterwards! Unfortunately there were no banana and chocolate crepes that day so we left without dessert, however the cabinet was well stocked with Mediterranean treats including baklava, Turkish delight, nougat etc. The menu seems perfect for sharing with an a multitude of cold and hot mezze items, pizza, salad, and more substantial meals. Would go back if I'm ever craving Mediterranean.

Luka keeps this portion of Tanjong Pagar Rd from being Little Korea. Luka does many classic Italian pasta and pizza dishes along with some pretty exotic ingredients that reveal chef Okuno's Japanese heritage. The octopus and sausage pasta and MENTAIKO & IKURA CREAM SAUCE are good examples of this fusion. Peroni is the only beer on tap or bottle, thought the liquor selection is extensive. Service was quick and the food was very good, indeed. The pizzas lived up to expectations even if the burrata was a shade dry. Great little gem for Italian in a sea of Korean and Japanese joints.
Good ambiance and great service. Pizza was alright but pastas were a better choice! Pretty good value though

address: 15 Enggor Street #01-01, Stall-7 Realty Centre Realty Food House Singapore 079716 Singapore
comment: The Penang laksa I had 2 days ago was very good. Ordered the $5 bowl which doesn't have much sardines. Just add $0.50 sardines and you get one whole sardine with lots of fish meat. Really worth it!Yesterday I tried vinegar pig's trotter for the first time. It's quite good. Skin and fats were melt in the mouth good. Which do I like best?I love love the Penang laksa!

We stumbled into this thanks to Yelp, and were very happy. The service was fast, knowledgeable, and friendly. And the dishes overall were excellent. We had two kinds of chicken, both perfectly cooked and flavorful, with fresh garlic naan. The fried cauliflower had too much goop on it for our tastes, but otherwise this was perfect.

This is one of the best Indian food I've had in a very very long time. From the moment we arrived the service was amazing and the food....Wow! Absolutely mouth watering delicious. Had several orders of the garlic naan, the Punjabi Chana, and dal tadka. They made it vegan for our family and it was sooo good. Best meal in Singapore so far!
Decent food but questionable value for money. Worthy if you have a significant discount through apps like Eatigo. May come back if I am in the area but unlikely I will go out of my way to come back

I was a huge Anjappar fan for the longest time. HUGE. But now, I've found a new love, Indline, The Indian Cookery. Thanks Deliveroo for the introduction ;)I can honestly say that food here is some of the best Indian food I've ever tried. It's not water down and the spices are so flavorful! Here's what we had, Butter chicken - This was fabulous. I know, I know butter chicken, ain't REAL Indian. But it's a classic dish now, and this place does it well! Lamb biryani - Lots of lamb! Lots of ghee! Lots of love! Bhindi masala - nom! Nom! Lady fingers in masala. You can't go wrong with this. Tandoori roti- I think this must have been my favorite out of the three, and how is that even possible? It's just roti! But they made it that goooooood. I def. recommend this place! I have yet to pop by the restaurant so I can't comment too much about the atmosphere. But, food, LOOOOVEEE!
Fully agree with Thomas. Food was ok but service was terrible. We only got half of our order after long wait. Luckily our friendly neighbour shared napkins with us ;)

'Been a long time since I was impressed enough to leave a review.  Food was fantastic in a pleasant/ simple but clean/ crisp surroundings.  Both the chicken and lamb were great cuts of meat and cooked perfectly.  Prices are also very reasonable.  I am here for only one more week but I will be back!

Food was authentic North Indian cuisine. Garlic naan was cooked in the tandoor to perfection. Butter chicken was meaty and creamy, the colour of the curry was perfect. Servers were friendly and knowledgable. Indoor or outdoor seating, great people watching spot on Keong Saik Rd. They had Kingfisher beer available on the menu. Lassi options are mango or rose, both tasted great. Wide selection of food on the menu, will definitely be back for more!

Upholding the same standards as the other location we've been to, TMP offers a great selection of western and Singaporean dishes (albeit slightly on the pricier side unless you have the Entertainer App like we do) along with a good hotel lobby ambience and friendly staff. Nothing spectacular but fits the bill of a weekend brunch spot with a group of friends in the city core where you don't have to fight for a spot or have a table booked (even on Sundays)

address: 32 Maxwell Rd #01-07 Maxwell Chambers Singapore 069115 Singapore
comment: Would highly recommend whether you go for a date, to catch up with friends or just to escape the heat. It's very spacious and service is on point. I thought that given how pretty it is the food / drink may not be that great but the strawberry cake was really delicious. The flavored beer is also delicious if you're into beer

Excellent old school Sui Gao (dumpling) noodle. The 3 dumplings are large (as they ought to be) and have ample minced pork filling with detectable fresh shrimp and water chestnut. Slightly thicker type noodles were cooked just right. The sauce is slightly sweet but balanced by the perfectly portioned green yu choy, mushroom slices and crispy pork lard. The accompanied dark chilli sauce is well made and should be mixed into the noodles to lessen its sweetness. A satisfying Michelin Plate for $4.50.

Ji Ji Noodle House is one of the food stalls that you must patronise if you are at Hong Lim Food Complex. This is also one of the stalls recommended by Michelin Guide.  They occupy 2 shop spaces side by side in the hawker centre with one side as storage and the other as ordering area.Even on a Saturday morning, the queue was overwhelmed. It took us about 30 minutes to get the order.We have Fried Chicken Cutlet to share among ourselves. Frying to golden brown in its crispy skin and coated with some chilli sauce.The meat was both juicy and tender.There are numerous dishes on their menu and one of the popular ones will be their Signature Noodle. Their noodles are sold at 4 prices $4.50 / 5.50 / 6.50 / 8.50. The bowl of Signature noodles was generously loaded with ingredients like Char Siew Slices, minced pork, braised mushrooms, wantons, pork lard as well as greens.I was swept away by how flavourful and by its piquant taste when I had the first mouthful. It has a unique fragrant that was not commonly found in normal hawker noodles on top of those pork lard bits. Texture of the noodle is springy too.There are a number of fried wantons as well as the normally boiled wantons. The fried ones were good with their thin and crispy skin.Char Siew was tender and great pairing with the noodle sauces.Not only was the food above average, the lady who serves the customers was friendly despite a busy queue ahead. I don't mind going back again for great service and food.

This have been one of my favorite wanton noodles stall. I have been avoiding it becos the taste is so good and it's almost addictive.The regular must have know the huge amount of pork lard hidden, chopped so small yet crunchy, so small that I cannot seem to find them to remove them. This "hidden" secret naturally add to the tastiness.I had the Dumplings version of the noodles. The dumpling probably didn't get to soak cooked long enough becos it like almost solid hardness for dumplings. The prawns embedded in these jello rocks is fresh and crunchy. The mushrooms in the sauce, and the sauce liberally soaking the noodles is probably the other secret. Now I remember that they don't clip off the stems of the mushrooms. Those stems are hard to chew, probably cause a few people to dislocate their dentures.The texture of the noodles is probably not as chewy as the other famous wanton noodle place, but when all the above combined the noodles dish itself taste wonderful.They lost one star for the dumpling, which I am pretty sure if they had less Q, this problem disappears.I won't return too much since I cannot remove those tasty pork lard crunchy crumbs.

Read about its wanton noodles and I decided to give it a try as I'm in the neighbourhood. Definitely not the food-court-taste wanton noodles. I had the char siew wanton and added the fried wantons for extra dollar.

Dropped in on a busy Sunday at lunchtime, and this double stall caught my eye because it is nice and colourful with lots of awards on it. Ordered up the large wonton noodles for $5 and overall it was very good. As others have said, the portions are large and the ingredients go beyond what other stalls offer.In the dish there were two types of wontons - fried (which were average) and boiled pork with prawns (which were amazing). There is also some Chinese cabbage and mushrooms which were a nice touch. The biggest downside was the noodles, seriously they need to improve the quality of these - just tasted wrong. Lastly, the sauce was a bit terrible, it wasn't a soup-style dredging of it which is good. Next time, go with the boiled wontons, extra vegetables and less of everything else.

Great food, great location, great staff! The restaurant is located on the second floor, right on Club Street. Do go for dinner there and head out for drinks to the surrounding bars afterwards. Also, Wednesdays is Oyster Day! Fresh, delicious and affordable :)

I love this place. It's an all time favourite of mine. Try the diced chilli chicken, chilli oil boiled pork & the water cooked fish with sprouts in chilli oil... All favourites of mine. The meat skewers are terrific too..! The service here is very attentive & this place is open till very late. If you like Chinese food & especially if you enjoy spicy Sichuan Chinese food, then this is the place to visit :)

Another great Chinese restaurant located smack dab in the middle of China town.   Went here during national day weekend, I like this place because they also have inside seating with AC.  The food was great and can't beat the prices here in Chinatown.   Excellent service, they also have nice uniforms that a more traditional. I wasn't able to enjoy the awesome selection of seafood here because one of our friends has a shellfish allergy.
The deep fried pig intestine and spicy pork ribs were crispy and tasty.  The pig ear was nicely gelatinous while the fish was garnished well.

Another great Szechuan cuisine restaurant - and very popular at that - so you may find yourself in the side place if you don't make reservations. One serious warning: try to go there with Chinese: the first time, I did and I had an excellent experience with an overwhelming choice of tasty dishes - spicy, yes, but not too much so. The second time, I went alone and I made all the wrong choices: the French beans were all dente but soooo hot I couldn't eat more than a few!

My family & I love this restaurant & also known as Golden Spoon. Die die must try their famous signature dish, crab with bee hoon soup. The soup is so tasty & the crab is fresh. Their appetiser - deep fried oyster roll with mayo is delicious, too. We love their fresh fish & vegetables & as if we're dining in one of the good restaurants in Hongkong. Noticed lots of expatriates dining in this restaurant. The boss told me that he has lots of dining places & Red House Seafood is one of them. Prices are reasonable. This restaurant is always packed & so is their car-park lots. Worth your calories.

A classic tze char restaurant with competent food and reasonable prices to boot. Tried their signature crab bee hoon and it was on point. Crab was big and fresh and fleshy. The stock was robust with wok hei and the bee hoon soaked them all up. The coffee pork ribs were very aromatic and well marinated and the HK steam fish (we took soon hock) was fresh and steamed just nice. Service was fast and polite.

It's been a while since I've been here. I stayed away after hearing news that the chef was different, but came back cos apparently he's back. The crab beehoon was still good. I liked the gravy A LOT. Some must orders: crispy squid and their crispy tofu. Both were standout dishes that got everyone in my party fighting for thirds. Haha

A fairly typical Chinese restaurant serving up the usual dishes, the one reason why I keep going back to Golden Spoon is for their crabs, specifically their Crab Bee Hoon. Located in the heart of Tiong Bahru, near the market, parking is relatively easy as there are a lot of lots to be found just in front of the restaurant. The only issues I have are with the staff, who don't really seem to understand you, so patience is definitely required. One thing to note when dining, especially when you're going for the signature Crab Beehoon, is that the later you go, the higher the chances are that you'll end up with only the larger crabs left. Meaning if you're planning on going on a date, its best to get there early to choose a smaller crab or you'll end up like me having a 1.8kg crab to share with my friend, which honestly, is a little too big!

Great crab bee hoon. Although I have to admit, I haven't had crab bee hoon anywhere else, I can't imagine it being any better than this anywhere else. Another hidden gem is the cereal tofu - think cereal prawns, but with less cholesterol. Chunks of egg tofu coated in garlicky corn flakes and deep fried, but the kicker is the sweet pumpkin sauce underneath. You don't get that with the prawns, and it's great. I just found out that this isn't even on the menu anymore, but they'll still make it if you ask.

Another one of my local favorites. The chilli crab is really good here, and is the mee goreng. I also tend to order the famous crab bee hoon, but for me it's slightly inconsistent- sometimes good, sometimes not memorable. The drunken prawns are another of my favorite orders here, and my wife, loves them. The broth is strong, and the prawns very fresh. The pumpkin sauce tofu is also delicious. There is much more seating outside than inside, and sometimes the fact that it is right in the car park might be irksome. Once, during the the height of CNY, they set up a tented area next to their restaurant, and the breeze was very welcome there. Also, BYOB is free. Highly recommended.

Update based on a visit a few weeks ago: the crab bee hoon unfortunately lacked a rich crab flavor.  The crab itself was tender and sweet, but the bee hoon was lacking salt or something.  The cereal tofu is also now an off menu item.  It is still one of the best dishes here (my out of town friend agreed)!
Came to Singapore for chili crab and was not disappointed. Taste just like I remembered it. And the rest of their seafood is delicious and fresh too. A little tricky to find, but plenty of parking.

For this Chinese restaurant, it is recommended to make reservation at least a few hours before. Waited sometime for the table but it's was all worth it! Food came out promptly and service was good despite the huge crowd.Crab bee hoon: soup is really tasty and blends really well with the bee hoon. The crab is really fresh and big. Their most popular dish.Thai style pig trotter: one of the best I've eaten. The sauce is not too sweet and goes really well with the crispy skin and tender, juicy meat. A must try!Cereal tofu with pumpkin sauce: cereal is very crispy. Egg tofu fried in cubes. The creamy pumpkin sauce has a tinge of sweetness which blends perfectly with the cereal and tofu. Another awesome dish here.

Really really really good crab bee hoon!!! It looks like like crab sitting in a bowl of dirty water with noodles but its excellent! I've been back twice in the last month for the bee hoon!  Cereal prawns are also a must order!

Didn't know that they've had 3 branches! I'm a fan of this porridge stall. They serve well cooked porridge that is piping hot. You almost thought you're eating baby food! porridge is gooey and really cooked for a long time. I ordered the century egg and pork porridge. I've no complaints except that some slices of pork was a little tough. I just love the way how the hawker used the fried dough or fritters to decorate the porridge. Those were fresh fried fritters with a good crust on it. Simple things like the neat way to cut the fritters in a round shape just shows the spirit of excellence. Good job and good comfort food for the day!

We had very bad jetlag and were up at 5am, hungry. Luckily, Zhen Zhen was nearby. The hawker centre was quiet except for a few stalls that early in the morning. Since we were planning to eat at many places that day, we decided to get one medium order of fish porridge to share. We took our nice warm bowl of porridge, which turned out to be bigger than expected, to a nearby table and dug in. It was so creamy and rich, yet in a subtle way. I could tell I was enjoying it more than he was and I didn't mind when he let me have more than half of the bowl. Out of all 5 hawker stalls we visited during our short Singapore trip, Zhen Zhen was hands down my favorite. It felt so comforting eating this porridge.

though it is truly (zhen de) authentically traditional type of porridge/congee, it has really nothing to rave about apart from being affordable(in price) esp u have to queue for it... hence the ability to q at the right timing is important ....at least it is not a disappointmentI felt the cooked porridge is too mushy till i can NO longer recognise it is made of rice

I don't know what the hype is about this place. Really disappointed, feel that the porridge is quite watered down and lacking in taste. The average porridge in HK is significantly better. We tried the fish porridge so the other ones might be better/why ppl like it but I wouldn't go back...

Food: 3.5/5.0Service: 1.5/5.0Value: 3.5/5.0Decor: 1.5/5.0Overall: 3.5/5.0Don't hate me, but I think Zhen Zhen is a bit overrated.  The porridge is good, but it was a letdown v. the hype and when it's not that great, I suddenly care more about the sloppiness of the preparation and presentation, etc.

My favorite congee (porridge) hawker stand in Singapore. I came for an early lunch when there was no long line. Normally have to wait 30-45 minutes to get your food.It is so creamy and delicious, I know of no other place anywhere that has rice porridge as awesome as this place.

We were at the Maxwell Centre around 9 am or so and decided some congee would be the perfect breakfast.  We ordered a century egg and chicken to share and it was fantastic.  Very flavorful and the best way to start a day.  The only reason I'm knocking off a star is because as we got to the bottom of the bowl, it got overly salty.  Perhaps we just need to mix it a bit more in the beginning.

This place reminds me so much of the soup Nazi in Seinfeld. You MUST follow the correct line and correct order procedure or else you will get a earful from the auntie. This always cracks me up when I am ordering porridge or congee to those from overseas. Line on the right - order. Line on the left - pick up. Porridge portions are generous, with spring onions, ginger and pepper. Varieties are fish slices , sliced pork, century egg, fish stomach. You can do various combinations of course. Price wise, S$3 up.Taste wise, yummy delicious! Be armed with a cold drink as you are sure to perspire when eating the piping hot porridge. Shiok!

Porridge is pretty close to my heart. I've had a few varieties in some great places. This absolutely knocks it out of the park. The pure comfort food goodness sends positive waves throughout your body.  Little else is noticed when partaking in this delight. It is Creamy, salty, meaty, herbaceous celebration in your mouth. If you make it to Singapore, it's a must try.
Good jook Cantonese style. S$3 for a small bowl. Fish could have been bigger pieces.

Really good porridge,  but I prefer porridge with thicker consistency. It is smooth and you can't taste the rice texture in their congee at all. I can see why some people love their congee for the smooth texture, but I personally find it is too smooth to be considered porridge - more like blended rice soup. Really generous portion, with great taste. They don't heat up individual serving of porridge when customers place their orders, which is a no-no for me too. Porridge ends up being lukewarm when served with a raw egg. In theory, porridge is supposed to be piping hot and the egg will be cooked instantaneously when added to the porridge.

This is the longest I've ever had to wait for a simple bowl of congee but boy was it worth it. The lady running the store may be the meanest and most sarcastic person I've ever met but that 10 seconds of interaction would hardly change my appreciation of how well they cook their food here. First thing, get the smallest bowl of congee ($3). It's has more than enough in it to fill you up. Getting anything bigger would be overkill. Secondly, get the Yu Sheng/Fish Salad, it's layered with so many flavors and textural contrasts and it would only set you back $3. Now I've got to start planning when I'm going back.

I don't know what the hype is about this place. Really disappointed, feel that the porridge is quite watered down and lacking in taste. The average porridge in HK is significantly better. We tried the fish porridge so the other ones might be better/why ppl like it but I wouldn't go back...

though it is truly (zhen de) authentically traditional type of porridge/congee, it has really nothing to rave about apart from being affordable(in price) esp u have to queue for it... hence the ability to q at the right timing is important ....at least it is not a disappointmentI felt the cooked porridge is too mushy till i can NO longer recognise it is made of rice

This is the best porridge I have ever tasted, and worth every minute of the 30 minutes we waited in line (at 11:25 am on a Thursday).  Porridge will never be the same for me, and every subsequent bowl will likely pale in comparison.  They have a vat of porridge cooking in the back of the stall, then each order is individually cooked with what you want added (thousand year egg, chicken, fish).  Each bowl is topped with pickle veggies, fried shallots, scallion, and remember to add some vinegar.We ordered the $3 bowl, #4, to share (we wanted to try other food as well) and it almost filled my wife and I.  Totally worth $3.

This place reminds me so much of the soup Nazi in Seinfeld. You MUST follow the correct line and correct order procedure or else you will get a earful from the auntie. This always cracks me up when I am ordering porridge or congee to those from overseas. Line on the right - order. Line on the left - pick up. Porridge portions are generous, with spring onions, ginger and pepper. Varieties are fish slices , sliced pork, century egg, fish stomach. You can do various combinations of course. Price wise, S$3 up.Taste wise, yummy delicious! Be armed with a cold drink as you are sure to perspire when eating the piping hot porridge. Shiok!

My boyfriend and I were jetlagged on our first day in singapore and woke up at 4am really hungry. Luckily this place was open at 6am and the congee was really good and very cheap. Maxwell center is our favorite hawker center in singapore so far.
Good jook Cantonese style. S$3 for a small bowl. Fish could have been bigger pieces.

This may be a tourist point of view but this is the best porridge I've ever had, my husband agrees too. We went to Maxwell Food Centre early in the morning around 10:30 when most stalls are still closed. This one already has a long line. Being a tourist we thought if all the locals line up mean either cheap & decent food or really good food. There were about 8 ppl in front of us, boy it took 45 min til we got our porridge!!! There's a ginormous pot (more like a huge tank w an automatic stirrer) cooking the porridge, then the 1 and only chef move each porridge portion into small pots and cook w the meat of choice (fish, chicken, century old egg or combination).It was worth the wait!!! We got the small $3 bowl to share w fish, chicken, and century old egg. Wow big portion for $3.. We promised to save stomach space to eat  food from other stalls but everyone spoon we ate had meat/ egg in it, that's how much content it had. Most delicious and best deal of homemade like food we've ever gotten. By around lunch time the line has gotten longer around the corner!! Looks like this place opens at early 5:30 am til 2:30 pm and they are closed Tuesdays.

Feel like I may end up being smote by some Foodie God for not giving Zhen Zhen Fish Porridge a 5 star review but here goes.Do not underestimate the mettle of this store. Maxwell is a stone's throw from my office so I frequent it often enough to be certain that this mystical porridge holds an amazing sway over the masses - the storefront is almost never without a snaking queue. Waiting time is anywhere between 30 - 45 mins, so bring along a book or play many rounds of scramble with friends to avoid ending up questioning your sanity. Patience has never been one my strongest suits so the wait made me a tad grouchier and enraged my expectation of the food to a few notches too high.Let's start with the best bit of the meal. The yu-sheng was spot-on - I can almost confidently say it is the best I have tasted in Singapore. Fresh fish slices are lightly marinated before being tossed with fragrant sesame seeds and crunchy spring onions. Patrons get to top it off by squeezing on some zesty lime juice. The hawker lady generously threw 6 limes into my box of $5 yu-sheng and I was a little perplexed by this plentitude but decided to go for 3 which turned out just perfect.   On to the porridge. The uniform consistency of the thick white gruel is certainly a feat. Every single rice grain has been subjected to prolonged methodical stirring that has ensured the gruel's acclaimed homogenity. And therein may also lie the reason as to why I am a staunch 4-star fan - being Teochew, my ideal porridge has got to have fluffy bits of rice grains still intact so this doesn't quite cut it for me.Despite my irrational porridge discrimination, I must say that stall is generous with the ingredients that go into each bowl. I ordered the century egg and sliced fish porridge and had a sliver of meat to go with every single spoonful - a rarity nowadays. All in all, try this if you aren't going to lose your temper over the wait. I am definitely more of a true blue Zhen Zhen Yu Sheng fan.

Undoubtedly my favorite stall at Maxwell Food Centre! It serves the best yu sheng (aka raw fish) in Singapore, and unbelievably smooth congee. The yu sheng tastes good because there is no bone (there are so many out there which has small bones still stuck on the fish) and are sliced thinly. It tastes good with the sesame oil, black and white sesame seeds, and the garnish. For the porridge, even if you order the plain one, trust me it's smooth and tasty. It probably does not have the Crystal Jade plain porridge standard, but with the generous amount of sesame oil and sesame seeds, it's perfect to go along with the yu sheng.It gets sold out pretty early, and the wait can be pretty long. But I assure you that this is definitely worth the wait!

We had very bad jetlag and were up at 5am, hungry. Luckily, Zhen Zhen was nearby. The hawker centre was quiet except for a few stalls that early in the morning. Since we were planning to eat at many places that day, we decided to get one medium order of fish porridge to share. We took our nice warm bowl of porridge, which turned out to be bigger than expected, to a nearby table and dug in. It was so creamy and rich, yet in a subtle way. I could tell I was enjoying it more than he was and I didn't mind when he let me have more than half of the bowl. Out of all 5 hawker stalls we visited during our short Singapore trip, Zhen Zhen was hands down my favorite. It felt so comforting eating this porridge.

though it is truly (zhen de) authentically traditional type of porridge/congee, it has really nothing to rave about apart from being affordable(in price) esp u have to queue for it... hence the ability to q at the right timing is important ....at least it is not a disappointmentI felt the cooked porridge is too mushy till i can NO longer recognise it is made of rice

I don't know what the hype is about this place. Really disappointed, feel that the porridge is quite watered down and lacking in taste. The average porridge in HK is significantly better. We tried the fish porridge so the other ones might be better/why ppl like it but I wouldn't go back...

Food: 3.5/5.0Service: 1.5/5.0Value: 3.5/5.0Decor: 1.5/5.0Overall: 3.5/5.0Don't hate me, but I think Zhen Zhen is a bit overrated.  The porridge is good, but it was a letdown v. the hype and when it's not that great, I suddenly care more about the sloppiness of the preparation and presentation, etc.

My favorite congee (porridge) hawker stand in Singapore. I came for an early lunch when there was no long line. Normally have to wait 30-45 minutes to get your food.It is so creamy and delicious, I know of no other place anywhere that has rice porridge as awesome as this place.

We were at the Maxwell Centre around 9 am or so and decided some congee would be the perfect breakfast.  We ordered a century egg and chicken to share and it was fantastic.  Very flavorful and the best way to start a day.  The only reason I'm knocking off a star is because as we got to the bottom of the bowl, it got overly salty.  Perhaps we just need to mix it a bit more in the beginning.

This place reminds me so much of the soup Nazi in Seinfeld. You MUST follow the correct line and correct order procedure or else you will get a earful from the auntie. This always cracks me up when I am ordering porridge or congee to those from overseas. Line on the right - order. Line on the left - pick up. Porridge portions are generous, with spring onions, ginger and pepper. Varieties are fish slices , sliced pork, century egg, fish stomach. You can do various combinations of course. Price wise, S$3 up.Taste wise, yummy delicious! Be armed with a cold drink as you are sure to perspire when eating the piping hot porridge. Shiok!

Porridge is pretty close to my heart. I've had a few varieties in some great places. This absolutely knocks it out of the park. The pure comfort food goodness sends positive waves throughout your body.  Little else is noticed when partaking in this delight. It is Creamy, salty, meaty, herbaceous celebration in your mouth. If you make it to Singapore, it's a must try.
Good jook Cantonese style. S$3 for a small bowl. Fish could have been bigger pieces.

Really good porridge,  but I prefer porridge with thicker consistency. It is smooth and you can't taste the rice texture in their congee at all. I can see why some people love their congee for the smooth texture, but I personally find it is too smooth to be considered porridge - more like blended rice soup. Really generous portion, with great taste. They don't heat up individual serving of porridge when customers place their orders, which is a no-no for me too. Porridge ends up being lukewarm when served with a raw egg. In theory, porridge is supposed to be piping hot and the egg will be cooked instantaneously when added to the porridge.

This is the longest I've ever had to wait for a simple bowl of congee but boy was it worth it. The lady running the store may be the meanest and most sarcastic person I've ever met but that 10 seconds of interaction would hardly change my appreciation of how well they cook their food here. First thing, get the smallest bowl of congee ($3). It's has more than enough in it to fill you up. Getting anything bigger would be overkill. Secondly, get the Yu Sheng/Fish Salad, it's layered with so many flavors and textural contrasts and it would only set you back $3. Now I've got to start planning when I'm going back.

I don't know what the hype is about this place. Really disappointed, feel that the porridge is quite watered down and lacking in taste. The average porridge in HK is significantly better. We tried the fish porridge so the other ones might be better/why ppl like it but I wouldn't go back...

though it is truly (zhen de) authentically traditional type of porridge/congee, it has really nothing to rave about apart from being affordable(in price) esp u have to queue for it... hence the ability to q at the right timing is important ....at least it is not a disappointmentI felt the cooked porridge is too mushy till i can NO longer recognise it is made of rice

This is the best porridge I have ever tasted, and worth every minute of the 30 minutes we waited in line (at 11:25 am on a Thursday).  Porridge will never be the same for me, and every subsequent bowl will likely pale in comparison.  They have a vat of porridge cooking in the back of the stall, then each order is individually cooked with what you want added (thousand year egg, chicken, fish).  Each bowl is topped with pickle veggies, fried shallots, scallion, and remember to add some vinegar.We ordered the $3 bowl, #4, to share (we wanted to try other food as well) and it almost filled my wife and I.  Totally worth $3.

This place reminds me so much of the soup Nazi in Seinfeld. You MUST follow the correct line and correct order procedure or else you will get a earful from the auntie. This always cracks me up when I am ordering porridge or congee to those from overseas. Line on the right - order. Line on the left - pick up. Porridge portions are generous, with spring onions, ginger and pepper. Varieties are fish slices , sliced pork, century egg, fish stomach. You can do various combinations of course. Price wise, S$3 up.Taste wise, yummy delicious! Be armed with a cold drink as you are sure to perspire when eating the piping hot porridge. Shiok!

My boyfriend and I were jetlagged on our first day in singapore and woke up at 4am really hungry. Luckily this place was open at 6am and the congee was really good and very cheap. Maxwell center is our favorite hawker center in singapore so far.
